Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: II-XII intact. Pupils equal, round, reactive to light and accommodation. Visual fields full to confrontation. Fundoscopy: Optic discs sharp, no papilledema, normal retinal vasculature.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Normal muscle tone, bulk, and power (5/5) in all four limbs. No pronator drift.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Intact to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception throughout.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Deep tendon reflexes 2+ and symmetrical. Plantar responses flexor bilaterally.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar_Function: Finger-nose and heel-shin tests normal. No dysdiadochokinesia.
Neurological_Examination.Gait: Normal gait and station.
Neurological_Examination.Meningeal_Signs: No neck stiffness. Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs negative.

Head_Neck_Examination.Temporal_Arteries: Temporal arteries normal, non-tender, pulsations present.
Head_Neck_Examination.Sinus_Tenderness: No tenderness over frontal or maxillary sinuses.
Head_Neck_Examination.TMJ: No tenderness or crepitus over temporomandibular joints.

MRI_Brain_with_and_without_contrast.Reason_for_ordering: To rule out structural intracranial pathology given chronic, worsening headaches.
MRI_Brain_with_and_without_contrast.Findings: Normal brain parenchyma, ventricular system, and cisterns. No evidence of mass lesion, acute infarct, hemorrhage, hydrocephalus, or abnormal enhancement. No signs of intracranial hypertension or hypotension.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Drug-induced headache (Medication Overuse Headache)

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose a patient presenting with recurrent, severe, unilateral headaches accompanied by autonomic features, and differentiate from other common headache types and secondary causes.

Patient_Actor.History: Patient presents with a 3-month history of recurrent, severe headaches. She describes the pain as excruciating, sharp, and stabbing, localized around her right eye and extending to the right temple. Each episode lasts approximately 45-90 minutes. These headaches have been occurring in clusters, with 1-3 attacks per day, often waking her from sleep, for periods of 2-3 weeks, followed by remission periods lasting several months. She notes that during these headaches, she experiences right-sided tearing, redness of the right eye, right eyelid drooping, and a stuffy or runny nose exclusively on the right side. She feels very restless and agitated during the attacks, often pacing the room. She reports that alcohol, even in small amounts, can sometimes trigger an attack during a cluster period. She denies any preceding aura like visual disturbances or sensory symptoms before the headache. She mentions some neck tension which she attributes to stress from her studies, but denies true neck stiffness. No history of recent head trauma.

Secondary_Symptoms: Restlessness and agitation during headache attacks

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Mild seasonal allergies, managed with over-the-counter antihistamines as needed. No personal history of migraines. Vaccinations up to date.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Full-time graduate student, reports significant stress related to academic workload. Drinks 2-3 units of alcohol on weekends, but avoids it during headache clusters. Non-smoker. Denies illicit drug use.
Medications: Reports trying paracetamol and ibuprofen for headaches with no significant relief.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Positive for symptoms listed above during headache episodes. Between episodes, feels well. Denies fever, chills, significant weight loss, night sweats. No persistent visual disturbances (e.g., blurred vision, diplopia) between attacks. Mild photophobia and phonophobia during severe headache attacks, but not between them. Denies jaw claudication, scalp tenderness. No generalized weakness, numbness, tingling, or seizures. No history of syncope. Denies persistent cough, purulent nasal discharge, or facial pain suggestive of sinusitis between attacks.

General_Examination.Appearance: Appears well-nourished, in no acute distress. Alert and cooperative. Examined between headache episodes.

HEENT_Examination.Head: Normocephalic, atraumatic.
HEENT_Examination.Eyes: PERRLA, EOMI. Conjunctivae clear, sclera anicteric. No ptosis or proptosis noted between attacks. Visual acuity grossly normal.
HEENT_Examination.Nose: Nasal mucosa pink, no discharge noted. No septal deviation. No sinus tenderness on palpation over frontal or maxillary sinuses.
HEENT_Examination.Throat: Oropharynx clear, no erythema or exudates.

Neck_Examination.Palpation: Supple, no lymphadenopathy. Thyroid not enlarged. Mild bilateral paracervical muscle tenderness on deep palpation, patient attributes this to stress.
Neck_Examination.Range_of_Motion: Full active and passive range of motion.

Neurological_Examination.Mental_Status: Alert and oriented to person, place, time, and situation.
Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: II-XII grossly intact. Facial sensation and movement symmetrical. Visual fields full to confrontation. Fundoscopy reveals sharp optic disc margins bilaterally, no hemorrhages, exudates, or papilledema.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Strength 5/5 in all four limbs. Tone normal. No pronator drift.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Intact to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception throughout.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Deep tendon reflexes 2+ and symmetrical in upper and lower extremities. Plantar reflexes downgoing bilaterally.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar_Signs: Finger-nose-finger and heel-to-shin tests performed well. No dysmetria or ataxia.
Neurological_Examination.Gait: Normal gait, able to tandem walk.
Neurological_Examination.Meningeal_Signs: No nuchal rigidity. Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs negative.

Cardiovascular_Examination.Findings: Regular rate and rhythm, S1 S2 normal, no murmurs, rubs or gallops.

Respiratory_Examination.Findings: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes or crackles.

Blood_Tests.Comprehensive_Metabolic_Panel: Within normal limits (electrolytes, renal function, liver function all normal).

MRI_Brain_with_and_without_contrast.Findings: Normal brain parenchyma. No evidence of acute intracranial hemorrhage, mass lesion, infarction, or abnormal enhancement. Ventricles and sulci are normal for age. Incidental finding of minimal mucosal thickening in the right maxillary sinus, not deemed clinically significant and not correlating with the patient's specific headache pattern or timing. Pituitary gland appears normal.

MRA_Brain_and_Neck.Findings: No evidence of aneurysm, stenosis, dissection, or other vascular malformation in the intracranial or cervical arteries.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Dysautonomic cephalgia (consistent with a Trigeminal Autonomic Cephalalgia, likely Cluster Headache)

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess, investigate, and diagnose a patient presenting with acute onset headache, fever, and evolving neurological symptoms.

Patient_Actor.History: Patient presents to the Emergency Department with a 3-day history of progressively worsening headache, described as severe, global, and throbbing. She also reports fever, malaise, and nausea. Over the past 12 hours, her housemate noticed she has become increasingly confused and lethargic. She had a mild upper respiratory tract infection (sore throat, runny nose) about 10 days ago, which had resolved.

Secondary_Symptoms: Fever (subjective and measured up to 38.8°C at home)
Confusion (reported by housemate, e.g., forgetting conversations, unsure of the day)
Nausea (one episode of vomiting this morning)

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Childhood asthma, well-controlled, uses salbutamol inhaler as needed (last used >1 year ago). No history of migraines or recurrent severe headaches. No previous neurological illness. Vaccinations up to date as per national schedule.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: University student, lives in shared accommodation. Non-smoker, drinks alcohol socially (2-3 units on weekends). Denies illicit drug use. No recent travel outside the country. No known sick contacts with similar severe symptoms, though common colds were going around campus.
Patient_Actor.Medications: Paracetamol 1g taken 6 hours ago with minimal relief. Occasional oral contraceptive pill use (not current).

Review_of_Systems.General: Reports fatigue, loss of appetite. Denies significant weight loss.
Review_of_Systems.Neurological: Besides headache and confusion: denies focal weakness prior to presentation, denies seizures (though housemate is unsure if a brief staring spell occurred), denies visual disturbances (blurring, diplopia, photophobia initially, though light now bothers her mildly), denies hearing changes or tinnitus, denies frank vertigo. Denies history of head trauma.
Review_of_Systems.ENT: No current sore throat, earache, or sinus pain/pressure. Denies neck stiffness until today, now feels mildly stiff.
Review_of_Systems.Gastrointestinal: Nausea and one vomit. Denies abdominal pain, diarrhea, or constipation.
Review_of_Systems.Dermatological: Denies any new rashes or skin lesions. Denies easy bruising.

General_Examination.Appearance: Appears unwell, flushed, lethargic but rousable. Mildly distressed by headache.

Neurological_Examination.Mental_Status: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) 13/15 (E3 V4 M6 - opens eyes to voice, confused speech, obeys commands). Disoriented to time and place. Attention impaired. Short-term memory deficits noted.
Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: Pupils equal, round, reactive to light (3mm bilaterally). Fundoscopy: optic discs sharp, no papilledema, no hemorrhages. Extraocular movements intact, no nystagmus. Mild right facial asymmetry noted on smiling (subtle right lower facial weakness). Gag reflex present. Tongue midline.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Bulk and tone normal in all limbs. Power: 5/5 in left upper/lower limbs. Subtle pronator drift on the right. Power 4+/5 in right upper limb, 5/5 in right lower limb. No fasciculations.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Difficult to formally assess due to confusion, but withdraws to pain symmetrically. Reports light touch as equal bilaterally when attentive.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Deep tendon reflexes: Biceps ++ bilaterally, Triceps ++ bilaterally, Patellar +++ bilaterally, Achilles +++ bilaterally. Plantar response: downgoing bilaterally.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar_Signs: Finger-nose testing shows mild dysmetria on the right. Unable to perform heel-shin or tandem gait due to lethargy and unsteadiness.
Neurological_Examination.Meningeal_Signs: Mild neck stiffness present. Kernig's sign negative. Brudzinski's sign equivocal.

Other_Systems_Examination.Cardiovascular_Examination: Warm peripheries, capillary refill <2 seconds. S1 S2 normal, no murmurs.
Other_Systems_Examination.Respiratory_Examination: Chest clear to auscultation bilaterally, no added sounds.
Other_Systems_Examination.Abdominal_Examination: Soft, non-tender, no organomegaly. Bowel sounds present.
Other_Systems_Examination.Dermatological_Examination: No petechiae, purpura, or other rashes.

Full_Blood_Count.Differential: Neutrophils 60%, Lymphocytes 30% (Relative lymphocytosis for degree of neutrophilia)

Blood_Tests.Coagulation_Screen: PT, APTT, INR within normal limits.
Blood_Tests.Blood_Cultures: Pending (later reported as No Growth after 5 days)

CT_Brain_Non_Contrast.Findings: No evidence of acute intracranial hemorrhage, mass effect, or hydrocephalus. Subtle low attenuation noted in the left medial temporal lobe, difficult to definitively characterize - ?early ischemic change, ?artifact. Recommend MRI for further evaluation if clinically indicated.

MRI_Brain_with_and_without_Contrast.Findings: T2-weighted and FLAIR sequences demonstrate hyperintensity and swelling in the left medial temporal lobe, insular cortex, and cingulate gyrus. Areas of restricted diffusion are seen on DWI corresponding to these regions. Post-gadolinium T1-weighted images show patchy gyral enhancement in the affected areas. No evidence of mass lesion or acute hemorrhage. Findings are highly suggestive of viral encephalitis, with localization concerning for Herpes Simplex Virus.

CSF_Analysis.Glucose_Level: 3.5 mmol/L (Concurrent plasma glucose 6.2 mmol/L; CSF/plasma ratio: 0.56 - Normal)

Other_CSF_Tests.Cytology: No malignant cells seen. Reactive lymphocytes present.

EEG.Findings: Diffuse background slowing consistent with encephalopathy. Periodic lateralized epileptiform discharges (PLEDs) noted over the left temporal region, occurring at approximately 1 Hz.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV-1) Encephalitis

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose a patient presenting with headaches triggered by physical exertion.

Patient_Actor.History: Patient reports a 3-month history of headaches that occur exclusively during or immediately after intense cycling sessions. He describes the headaches as bilateral, throbbing, and severe, typically starting about 15-20 minutes into strenuous rides or sprints. The pain usually subsides within 1-2 hours of stopping exercise. He has no headaches at rest or with mild activity. He is worried because these headaches are affecting his training for an upcoming competition. He tried over-the-counter analgesics (ibuprofen, paracetamol) before exercise with minimal relief.
Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: History of a mild concussion 5 years ago from a cycling fall, with full recovery within 2 weeks. No history of migraines. Otherwise healthy.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Non-smoker, drinks alcohol socially (1-2 beers per week). Works as a graphic designer. Cycles 150-200km per week. Denies use of illicit drugs or performance-enhancing substances.
Patient_Actor.Family_History: Mother has history of migraines. Father has hypertension.

Review_of_Systems.General: Denies fever, chills, weight loss, night sweats.
Review_of_Systems.Neurological: Denies any 'worst headache of life' or sudden thunderclap onset. No visual disturbances (blurring, diplopia, visual field loss). No weakness, numbness, tingling, or speech difficulties. No seizures or loss of consciousness. No dizziness or vertigo. No neck stiffness or pain at rest. No preceding aura.
Review_of_Systems.Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain, palpitations, or undue shortness of breath during exertion (beyond expected for intense cycling).
Review_of_Systems.ENT: Denies nasal congestion, facial pain, or sinus pressure. Denies ear pain or discharge.
Review_of_Systems.Other: Denies recent major trauma. Denies changes in mood or cognition apart from frustration about the headaches.

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Well-developed, athletic build, in no acute distress at rest.

Neurological_Examination.Mental_Status: Alert and oriented x4, normal speech.
Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: II-XII intact. Pupils equal, round, reactive to light and accommodation. Fundoscopy normal, optic discs sharp, no papilledema, no hemorrhages.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Normal tone, bulk, and power (5/5) in all limbs. No pronator drift.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Intact to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception throughout.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Deep tendon reflexes 2+ and symmetric. Plantars downgoing bilaterally.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar_Function: Finger-nose-finger, heel-to-shin tests normal. No dysdiadochokinesia.
Neurological_Examination.Gait: Normal gait and tandem walking.
Neurological_Examination.Meningeal_Signs: No neck stiffness. Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs negative.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Cardiovascular_Examination: Regular rate and rhythm, S1 S2 normal, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Carotid pulses 2+ bilaterally, no bruits.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Respiratory_Examination: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes or crackles.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Head_and_Neck_Examination: No sinus tenderness on palpation. No temporal artery tenderness.

Blood_Tests.Full_Blood_Count: Hemoglobin 15.0 g/dL, WBC 6.5 x 10^9/L, Platelets 250 x 10^9/L (All within normal limits)
Blood_Tests.Urea_and_Electrolytes: Sodium 140 mmol/L, Potassium 4.2 mmol/L, Urea 5.0 mmol/L, Creatinine 80 µmol/L (All within normal limits)

CT_Brain_Non_Contrast.Indication: New onset exertional headaches to rule out intracranial hemorrhage or gross structural lesion.
CT_Brain_Non_Contrast.Findings: No evidence of acute intracranial hemorrhage, mass effect, or hydrocephalus. Grey-white matter differentiation preserved. Ventricles and sulci are normal for age. Basal cisterns are clear.

MRI_Brain_with_and_without_contrast_and_.Indication: Further evaluation of exertional headaches, CT brain normal. To rule out subtle structural lesions, vascular malformations, dissection, or signs of RCVS.
MRI_Brain_with_and_without_contrast_and_.Findings_MRI: Normal brain parenchyma. No evidence of tumor, infarct, inflammation, or demyelination. No abnormal enhancement post-contrast.
MRI_Brain_with_and_without_contrast_and_.Findings_MRA: Normal appearance of the intracranial and cervical arteries. No evidence of stenosis, aneurysm, dissection, or arteriovenous malformation. Normal flow-related signals.

ECG_12_lead.Indication: Screen for cardiac causes of exertional symptoms, although primary complaint is headache.
ECG_12_lead.Findings: Sinus rhythm, rate 60 bpm. Normal axis, intervals, and segments. No evidence of ischemia or arrhythmia.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Primary Exertional Headache

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess, diagnose, and initiate management for a patient presenting with acute headache and deteriorating neurological status following head trauma.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient, a 22-year-old male, was brought to the Emergency Department by his roommate due to worsening headache, vomiting, and increasing drowsiness. The patient fell while skateboarding approximately 4 hours ago, hitting the right side of his head. He reports being 'dazed' for about a minute immediately after the fall but did not lose consciousness completely by his account, and then felt 'fine' and went home. He 'walked it off'. Over the past 2 hours, he developed a severe, throbbing headache localized to the right side of his head, vomited twice (non-bloody, non-bilious), and became progressively more lethargic and confused. His roommate called emergency services when he became difficult to rouse.

Secondary_Symptoms: History of recent head trauma with brief alteration of consciousness

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: No significant past medical history. No previous head injuries or surgeries. No known bleeding disorders.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: University student. Occasional alcohol, denies smoking or illicit drug use. Active skateboarder.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Patient confirms recent head trauma with brief alteration of consciousness followed by a period of apparent normalcy ('lucid interval') before symptom onset. Denies any preceding illness, fever, chills, neck stiffness, or photophobia. No history of migraines or similar headaches. No known allergies. Denies chest pain, palpitations, or shortness of breath. Last meal was 5 hours ago.

General_Examination.Appearance: Appears drowsy, slow to respond to questions, but rousable to verbal stimuli.

Head_and_Neck_Examination.Scalp: Visible 3cm haematoma and tenderness over the right temporal region. No open wounds or palpable skull defect. No Battle's sign or raccoon eyes. No CSF rhinorrhoea or otorrhoea. Neck supple, no tenderness on palpation of cervical spine.

Neurological_Examination.Pupils: Right pupil 5mm and sluggishly reactive to light. Left pupil 3mm and briskly reactive to light. Anisocoria present.
Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: Right-sided ptosis noted. Impaired adduction, elevation, and depression of the right eye (partial CN III palsy). Facial sensation and power symmetrical (CN V, VII intact). Other cranial nerves II, IV, VI (left eye), VIII-XII appear grossly intact.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Reduced power (4/5) in the left upper and lower limbs. Normal power (5/5) in the right upper and lower limbs. Normal tone on the right, increased tone (spasticity) on the left.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Appears to withdraw to painful stimuli bilaterally, possibly less briskly on the left. Formal sensory testing limited by drowsiness.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Deep tendon reflexes +3 and brisk on the left side, +2 on the right. Left plantar response upgoing (positive Babinski sign). Right plantar response downgoing.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar_Examination: Coordination (finger-nose, heel-shin) and gait unable to be formally assessed due to drowsiness and weakness.
Neurological_Examination.Fundoscopy: Optic discs visualized bilaterally, margins appear sharp. No definite papilloedema. Venous pulsations present.

Other_Systems_Examination.Cardiovascular: Heart sounds S1, S2 normal. No murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Pulses full and regular.
Other_Systems_Examination.Respiratory: Chest clear to auscultation bilaterally. Good air entry. No added sounds.
Other_Systems_Examination.Abdominal: Soft, non-tender, non-distended. Bowel sounds present.

Blood_Tests.Group_and_Save: Blood group O positive, antibody screen negative.

CT_Brain_Non_Contrast.Findings: Large right-sided acute extradural hematoma in the temporoparietal region, measuring approximately 3.5cm in maximal thickness. Hematoma is biconvex (lentiform) in shape and hyperdense. An overlying linear, non-displaced fracture of the right temporal bone is noted. Significant mass effect is present, with approximately 1.2cm of right-to-left midline shift and effacement of the right lateral ventricle and suprasellar cistern. No evidence of subarachnoid, subdural or intracerebral hemorrhage elsewhere.

Cervical_Spine_CT.Findings: Alignment of the cervical spine is normal. No acute fracture or dislocation identified. Degenerative changes are not present.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Acute Extradural Haematoma (Epidural Hematoma)

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess a 68-year-old female presenting with persistent headaches and progressive visual disturbances, and formulate a differential diagnosis and management plan.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a 3-month history of intermittent frontal headaches, described as a dull ache. These headaches have gradually worsened in frequency and intensity, often more pronounced in the evenings or after prolonged reading or screen time. She also reports a gradual decline in her vision, needing more light to read, and has recently started noticing 'halos around streetlights at night'. She mentions feeling 'more clumsy lately', frequently bumping into objects on her right side. She initially attributed these symptoms to 'getting older' but is now concerned.

Secondary_Symptoms: Seeing halos around lights at night
Increased clumsiness (bumping into objects on the right)
Mild nausea occasionally accompanying severe headaches

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Hypertension, well-controlled. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus, diet-controlled. Reports using some 'steroid eye drops' prescribed by a GP for 'itchy eyes' about a year ago for a few weeks. No history of significant eye trauma or previous eye surgery.
Patient_Actor.Family_History: Mother had 'eye problems' and 'poor vision' in her old age, specific diagnosis unknown. No other known family history of significant eye conditions.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Retired teacher. Non-smoker. Drinks alcohol rarely (1-2 units per month). Lives alone.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Patient reports needing more light to read. Denies fever, chills, significant weight loss, night sweats. Denies jaw claudication, scalp tenderness, or new prominent temporal artery. No acute focal neurological deficits such as unilateral weakness, numbness, dysphasia, or new-onset seizures. Denies symptoms of acute sinusitis (e.g., purulent nasal discharge, facial pressure worsening on bending forward). No preceding aura, photophobia or phonophobia typical of migraine. Denies recent upper respiratory tract infection. Denies pulsatile tinnitus. No history of recent head trauma. Denies diplopia.

General_Examination.Appearance: Alert, oriented to time, place, and person. Appears mildly uncomfortable due to headache. No apparent distress.

Neurological_Examination.Mental_Status: Alert and oriented x3, normal speech.

CN_II_Optic.Visual_Acuity_Snellen: Right Eye (OD): 6/12 (pinhole to 6/9). Left Eye (OS): 6/9 (pinhole to 6/7).
CN_II_Optic.Visual_Fields_Confrontation: Constriction of superior and nasal visual fields in the right eye. Left eye full to confrontation.
CN_II_Optic.Pupils: Right pupil 3mm, Left pupil 3mm. Both reactive to light, however, a subtle relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is noted in the right eye on swinging flashlight test. Accommodation normal bilaterally.

Fundoscopy.Right_Eye_OD: Optic disc appears pale with significant cupping; cup-to-disc ratio estimated at 0.8. Visible thinning of the neuroretinal rim, particularly superiorly and inferiorly. A small flame-shaped hemorrhage noted at the inferotemporal disc margin. Retinal arterioles show moderate attenuation and AV nipping. Background retina otherwise unremarkable.
Fundoscopy.Left_Eye_OS: Optic disc shows mild cupping; cup-to-disc ratio estimated at 0.5. Neuroretinal rim appears largely intact but possibly thinner superiorly. Similar background vascular changes as the right eye. No hemorrhages or exudates.

CN_II_Optic.Color_Vision_Ishihara: Not formally tested but reports no recent change in color perception.

Cranial_Nerves.CN_III_Oculomotor_IV_Trochlear_VI_Abduce: Extraocular movements full and intact in all directions. No nystagmus. No ptosis.
Cranial_Nerves.CN_V_Trigeminal: Facial sensation intact to light touch in all three divisions bilaterally. Motor function (muscles of mastication) normal.
Cranial_Nerves.CN_VIII_Vestibulocochlear: Hearing grossly intact to whispered voice.
Cranial_Nerves.CN_IX_Glossopharyngeal_X_Vagus: Gag reflex present (not formally tested), uvula midline.
Cranial_Nerves.CN_XI_Accessory: Shoulder shrug and head turn against resistance normal.

Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Normal tone, bulk, and power (5/5) in all four limbs.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Intact to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception in all four limbs.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Deep tendon reflexes 2+ and symmetrical throughout. Plantar responses flexor bilaterally.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar_Function: Finger-nose test, heel-shin test normal. No dysdiadochokinesia.
Neurological_Examination.Gait: Normal gait and station. Romberg test negative.
Neurological_Examination.Meningeal_Signs: No neck stiffness. Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs negative.
Neurological_Examination.Temporal_Artery_Palpation: Temporal arteries palpable, non-tender, no nodules or decreased pulsation.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Cardiovascular_Examination: Regular rate and rhythm, S1 S2 normal, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Respiratory_Examination: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes or crackles.

Blood_Tests.Full_Blood_Count: Hemoglobin 13.5 g/dL, WBC 7.2 x 10^9/L, Platelets 250 x 10^9/L (All within normal limits)
Blood_Tests.Urea_and_Electrolytes: Sodium 140 mmol/L, Potassium 4.2 mmol/L, Urea 5.5 mmol/L, Creatinine 75 µmol/L (Normal)

CT_Brain_without_contrast.Reason_for_Scan: New onset persistent headache in an elderly patient with some visual symptoms.
CT_Brain_without_contrast.Findings: No acute intracranial hemorrhage, mass effect, midline shift, or significant territorial ischemic changes. Mild age-related diffuse cerebral atrophy and small vessel white matter ischemic changes noted. Ventricular system normal size. Orbits grossly unremarkable on limited views.

Gonioscopy.Right_Eye_OD: Open angle, Shaffer grade IV, no peripheral anterior synechiae, no neovascularization.
Gonioscopy.Left_Eye_OS: Open angle, Shaffer grade IV, no peripheral anterior synechiae, no neovascularization.

Automated_Perimetry_Humphrey_Visual_Fiel.Right_Eye_OD: Significant superior arcuate scotoma extending into a nasal step. Reduced mean deviation (-8.5 dB). Pattern standard deviation significantly increased.
Automated_Perimetry_Humphrey_Visual_Fiel.Left_Eye_OS: Early superior nasal depression and a few scattered non-specific points. Mean deviation (-2.1 dB).

Optical_Coherence_Tomography_OCT_Optic_N.Right_Eye_OD: Significant thinning of the retinal nerve fiber layer (RNFL) globally, most pronounced in the inferior and superior quadrants. Increased cup volume and area. Ganglion cell complex thinning.
Optical_Coherence_Tomography_OCT_Optic_N.Left_Eye_OS: Borderline RNFL thinning in the superior quadrant. Otherwise within normal limits for age.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Primary Open-Angle Glaucoma (POAG), more advanced in the right eye, with associated headaches likely secondary to elevated intraocular pressure.

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess, investigate, and diagnose a patient presenting with recurrent headaches and episodes of confusion.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a 2-week history of recurrent, dull, generalized headaches. These headaches often occur in the morning before breakfast, or if she skips a meal. She also reports several episodes in the past two weeks where she felt sweaty, shaky, anxious, had palpitations, and experienced mild confusion or difficulty concentrating. These episodes typically resolve within 10-15 minutes of consuming a sugary drink or snack. She mentions that she recently started a new exercise regimen (walking 30 minutes daily) and has been trying to 'eat healthier' by consuming smaller portions to better manage her diabetes.
Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for 10 years, mild hypertension. No history of seizures or previous significant neurological events. Denies previous similar episodes prior to the last two weeks.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Retired teacher, lives with her husband. Non-smoker, consumes alcohol rarely (one glass of wine per week). Reports good adherence to medications. No known drug allergies.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies fever, neck stiffness, photophobia, or phonophobia. No visual aura or persistent visual disturbances, though reports transient blurred vision during the 'shaky' episodes. No recent head trauma. No focal weakness, numbness, or speech disturbance. No seizures. Denies significant weight loss beyond intentional modest reduction. No chest pain, shortness of breath, persistent nausea, vomiting, or changes in bowel or bladder habits. No skin rashes or joint pains.

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Appears alert and oriented to time, place, and person. Mildly anxious. Palms are slightly moist. No pallor or jaundice.

Neurological_Examination.Mental_Status: Alert, oriented x3. Speech is clear and coherent. Attention and concentration appear normal during examination (patient reports current symptoms are mild).
Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: II-XII intact. Pupils equal, round, reactive to light and accommodation. Fundoscopy reveals no papilloedema, normal optic discs.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Normal bulk, tone, and power (5/5) in all four limbs. Fine tremor noted in outstretched hands.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Intact to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Deep tendon reflexes 2+ and symmetrical throughout.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar_Function: Finger-nose and heel-shin tests normal. No dysdiadochokinesia.
Neurological_Examination.Gait: Normal gait.
Neurological_Examination.Meningeal_Signs: No neck stiffness. Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs negative.

Cardiovascular_Examination.Palpation: Apex beat not displaced. No heaves or thrills.
Cardiovascular_Examination.Auscultation: S1 and S2 normal. Regular rhythm. No murmurs, rubs, or gallops.

Respiratory_Examination.Auscultation: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes or crackles.

Abdominal_Examination.Inspection: Abdomen flat, no scars or distension.
Abdominal_Examination.Palpation: Soft, non-tender. No hepatosplenomegaly or masses palpated.

Bedside_Tests.Capillary_Blood_Glucose: 2.8 mmol/L (50 mg/dL) - *performed while patient was feeling mildly symptomatic with headache and slight tremor*

Glucose_Metabolism.Fasting_Plasma_Glucose_Lab: 2.9 mmol/L (Normal: 3.9-5.5) - *confirmatory sample drawn at time of low CBG*
Glucose_Metabolism.HbA1c: 7.2% (55 mmol/mol) (Target for many T2DM: <7.0% or individualized)

CT_Brain_without_contrast.Reason_for_ordering: Recurrent headaches with episodes of confusion, to rule out intracranial pathology.
CT_Brain_without_contrast.Findings: No acute intracranial abnormality. Specifically, no evidence of acute infarct, haemorrhage, mass effect, or space-occupying lesion. Ventricular system and sulcal pattern are normal for age. Grey-white matter differentiation is preserved.

ECG.Intervals: PR, QRS, QTc within normal limits
ECG.ST_T_waves: No acute ST segment elevation or depression. No T wave inversion suggestive of ischemia.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Hypoglycaemia secondary to Gliclazide, likely exacerbated by increased physical activity and reduced carbohydrate intake.

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess, diagnose, and outline initial management for a patient presenting with progressive headache and neurological symptoms.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient, a 45-year-old male, presents with a two-week history of progressively worsening headache. Initially dull, it is now a severe, throbbing, left-sided pain (8/10), exacerbated by coughing and typically worse in the mornings. Over-the-counter analgesics provide no relief. For the past week, he has experienced nausea, with one episode of vomiting yesterday. He also reports feeling 'slower' mentally and noticing increasing clumsiness in his right hand. He mentions having intermittent low-grade fevers (up to 38.0°C) over the last few days. He has a history of chronic sinusitis and recalls a significant flare-up about four weeks ago, which he self-managed with decongestants.
Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Chronic sinusitis. No history of migraines, epilepsy, or previous intracranial surgery. No known immunodeficiency.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Non-smoker, occasional alcohol use. Works as an accountant. No illicit drug use.
Medications: Paracetamol and ibuprofen for current headache (ineffective)
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Patient reports worsening left-sided headache, nausea, and recent right-hand clumsiness. Notes intermittent low-grade fevers. Denies prior history of similar headaches or migraines, no recent significant head trauma (minor bump to head 2 months ago, no LOC, no sequelae), no photophobia, no phonophobia, no overt seizures. Denies neck stiffness. Denies visual disturbances such as blurring or diplopia initially. Denies chest pain, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, urinary symptoms, or recent skin infections. No recent dental procedures.

General_Examination.Appearance: Appears uncomfortable and mildly lethargic. Well-nourished.

Neurological_Examination.Mental_Status: Alert, oriented to person and place, but slow to respond to questions. GCS 14 (E4, V4, M6 due to slowness/confusion).
Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: Pupils 3mm, equal, round, and reactive to light. Fundoscopy reveals bilateral papilledema. Visual fields full to confrontation. Mild right facial weakness (lower face, UMN pattern). Other cranial nerves II-XII grossly intact.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Reduced power (4/5) in the right upper and lower limbs. Normal power on the left. Tone normal throughout. Reflexes: Biceps, triceps, knee, and ankle jerks are brisker (3+) on the right side compared to the left (2+). Right plantar response is extensor, left is flexor.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Intact to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception bilaterally. No sensory level.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar_Signs: Mild dysmetria on finger-to-nose testing on the right. No dysdiadochokinesia. Gait not formally assessed due to weakness and lethargy.
Neurological_Examination.Meningeal_Signs: Neck supple. Kernig's sign negative. Brudzinski's sign negative.

ENT_Examination.Inspection: Nasal mucosa appears normal, no purulent discharge seen. Oropharynx clear.
ENT_Examination.Palpation: Mild tenderness elicited on palpation over the left maxillary sinus.

Other_System_Examinations.Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no added sounds.
Other_System_Examinations.Abdominal: Soft, non-tender, no organomegaly, bowel sounds present.

Blood_Tests.Blood_Cultures: Two sets taken, results pending (subsequently reported as No Growth after 5 days).

CT_Brain_Non_Contrast.Findings: Area of ill-defined low attenuation in the left frontal lobe with surrounding vasogenic edema. Mass effect evident with approximately 3mm of rightward midline shift. No evidence of acute hemorrhage.

CT_Brain_With_Contrast.Findings: Following contrast administration, a well-defined, peripherally enhancing lesion measuring approximately 3 cm in diameter is identified in the left frontal lobe, consistent with an abscess. Significant surrounding edema persists.

MRI_Brain_With_and_Without_Contrast_incl.Findings: Confirms a 3.1 cm x 2.8 cm x 3.0 cm peripherally ring-enhancing lesion in the left frontal white matter. The central portion of the lesion demonstrates marked restricted diffusion on DWI sequences and low signal on ADC map, characteristic of pus. There is extensive surrounding T2/FLAIR hyperintensity representing vasogenic edema, causing effacement of the left lateral ventricle and approximately 4mm of subfalcine herniation to the right. No other lesions identified.

CT_Sinuses.Findings: Opacification of the left maxillary and frontal sinuses with some mucosal thickening, suggestive of chronic sinusitis with an acute component. No obvious bony erosion into the intracranial cavity seen on these sinus views.

Lumbar_Puncture.Reason: Contraindicated due to clinical and radiological signs of raised intracranial pressure and focal neurological deficit with a space-occupying lesion identified on CT scan, posing a high risk of cerebral herniation.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Intracranial abscess (left frontal lobe) secondary to paranasal sinusitis

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose a patient presenting with acute severe headache and neurological signs, and outline key management priorities.

Patient_Actor.History: Patient presents to the Emergency Department via ambulance with a sudden onset of severe, generalized headache that started approximately 2 hours ago. He describes it as 'the worst headache of my life.' Associated with nausea, one episode of vomiting, and photophobia. His wife reports he seemed confused and slurred his words for a few minutes but this improved slightly. He complains of some neck stiffness.
Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Hypertension (diagnosed 5 years ago, reports variable compliance with medication). Paroxysmal Atrial Fibrillation (diagnosed 2 years ago). No history of previous strokes, TIA, brain surgery, or known intracranial aneurysms. Denies history of migraines or similar headaches.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Retired accountant. Smokes 10 cigarettes per day (20 pack-year history). Drinks 2-3 units of alcohol per week. Lives with his wife. Denies illicit drug use.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies fever, chills, recent head trauma, seizures. Denies true visual loss or diplopia (other than general photophobia). Denies chest pain, palpitations, or shortness of breath. No abdominal pain, urinary or bowel symptoms. No recent illness, infections, or rash.

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Appears distressed, photophobic, frequently holding his head.

Neurological_Examination.Level_of_Consciousness: Alert but disoriented to time and place. Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) 14/15 (Eyes 4, Verbal 4, Motor 6).
Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: Pupils are 3mm, equal, round, and reactive to light bilaterally. Visual fields full to confrontation. Fundoscopy reveals sharp optic disc margins bilaterally, no papilloedema or haemorrhages. Mild left facial weakness, consistent with an upper motor neuron pattern. Speech demonstrates mild dysarthria.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Tone normal in all four limbs. Power in right upper and lower limbs 5/5. Power in left upper and lower limbs 4+/5. No pronator drift observed on the right; subtle left pronator drift present.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Deep tendon reflexes 2+ and symmetrical throughout. Plantar responses are downgoing bilaterally.
Neurological_Examination.Sensation: Intact to light touch and pinprick in all major dermatomes; formal sensory testing limited by patient's distress and cooperation.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar_Examination: Finger-nose testing reveals mild intention tremor on the left side. Unable to assess gait due to patient's acute condition and distress.
Neurological_Examination.Meningeal_Signs: Positive neck stiffness on passive flexion. Kernig's sign negative. Brudzinski's sign negative.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Cardiovascular_Examination: Heart sounds S1, S2 heard. Irregularly irregular rhythm. No murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Peripheral pulses (radial, dorsalis pedis) present and equal bilaterally.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Respiratory_Examination: Chest clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, crackles, or added sounds. Good air entry throughout.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Abdominal_Examination: Soft, non-tender, no guarding or rebound tenderness. No palpable organomegaly. Bowel sounds present and normal.

Blood_Tests.Full_Blood_Count: Hemoglobin 13.5 g/dL, White Blood Cell Count 11.2 x10^9/L (Neutrophils 75%, Lymphocytes 20%), Platelet Count 220 x10^9/L
Blood_Tests.Coagulation_Screen: Prothrombin Time (PT) 42 seconds, International Normalized Ratio (INR) 3.8, Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time (APTT) 35 seconds
Blood_Tests.Urea_and_Electrolytes: Sodium 138 mmol/L, Potassium 4.2 mmol/L, Urea 5.5 mmol/L, Creatinine 88 µmol/L, eGFR >60 mL/min/1.73m²
Blood_Tests.Liver_Function_Tests: Alanine Aminotransferase (ALT) 30 U/L, Aspartate Aminotransferase (AST) 35 U/L, Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP) 70 U/L, Total Bilirubin 10 µmol/L (all within normal limits)

CT_Brain_Non-Contrast.Findings: Extensive hyperdensity within the subarachnoid space, particularly prominent in the basal cisterns, Sylvian fissures, and interhemispheric fissure. Evidence of mild intraventricular hemorrhage, particularly in the fourth ventricle. A 2cm area of intraparenchymal hyperdensity is noted in the right temporal lobe consistent with an acute hematoma. No significant hydrocephalus or midline shift at present. No evidence of skull fracture.

CT_Angiogram_Brain.Findings: (Performed immediately following non-contrast CT) Reveals a 6mm saccular aneurysm arising from the bifurcation of the right Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA M1/M2 junction), consistent with the source of hemorrhage. No other aneurysms or arteriovenous malformations identified.

Chest_X-Ray (AP portable).Findings: Lungs are clear. Cardiomediastinal contour is within normal limits for age. No pleural effusion or pneumothorax. No acute bony abnormality.

ECG (12-lead).Findings: Atrial fibrillation with a ventricular rate of approximately 75-85 bpm. No acute ST-segment elevation or depression suggestive of myocardial ischemia. QTc interval normal.

Lumbar_Puncture.Findings: Not performed. Contraindicated due to positive CT findings of intracranial hemorrhage (both subarachnoid and intraparenchymal components) and the associated risk of cerebral herniation.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Acute Subarachnoid Haemorrhage (Hunt and Hess Grade III) with associated right temporal lobe intraparenchymal haemorrhage, secondary to a ruptured right Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) bifurcation aneurysm, in a patient on warfarin with supratherapeutic INR.

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess, investigate, and manage a young adult presenting with acute severe headache, fever, and altered mental status.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient is a 19-year-old university student brought to the Emergency Department by her roommate. She developed a severe headache over the past 12-18 hours, which has rapidly worsened. She reports feeling generally unwell with symptoms of a common cold (runny nose, mild cough, sore throat) about one week ago, which had mostly resolved. The headache is described as global, throbbing, and rated 10/10 in severity. It is associated with subjective fever, chills, significant neck stiffness/soreness, and marked photophobia. She vomited once this morning. Her roommate notes that she has become increasingly drowsy and seemed confused about what day it was prior to coming to the hospital.

Secondary_Symptoms: Nausea and one episode of vomiting

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: No significant past medical history. Up-to-date with childhood immunizations, but unsure about meningococcal vaccine status. No history of migraines.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Lives in a university dormitory. Non-smoker, occasional alcohol use. Denies illicit drug use.
Patient_Actor.Medications: Occasional paracetamol for mild headaches (ineffective for current headache). No regular medications. No known drug allergies.

Review_of_Systems.Neurological: Besides headache, photophobia, neck stiffness and mild confusion, denies focal weakness, numbness, seizures, visual disturbances (e.g. diplopia, blurred vision beyond general light sensitivity), or speech difficulties. Denies recent head trauma.
Review_of_Systems.ENT: Had a mild sore throat and runny nose last week, now resolved. Denies earache or sinus pain.
Review_of_Systems.Respiratory: Mild residual cough from recent cold. Denies shortness of breath or chest pain.
Review_of_Systems.Gastrointestinal: One episode of vomiting. Denies diarrhea or abdominal pain.
Review_of_Systems.Musculoskeletal: Reports severe neck stiffness. Denies other joint pain or muscle aches beyond generalized malaise.

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Appears acutely unwell, flushed, drowsy but rousable to voice. Mildly disoriented to time.

Neurological_Examination.Mental_Status: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) 14/15 (E4, V4 - confused, M6). Disoriented to day and date. Attentive but concentration poor.
Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: Pupils equal, round, reactive to light. Fundoscopy reveals no papilledema. Extraocular movements intact. Facial sensation and movement symmetrical. Other cranial nerves grossly intact.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Normal tone. Power 5/5 in all four limbs. No focal deficits.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Intact to light touch and pinprick throughout. No sensory level.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Deep tendon reflexes 2+ and symmetrical. Plantars downgoing bilaterally.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar_Function: Difficult to formally assess due to drowsiness and malaise, but no gross ataxia noted when moving in bed.
Neurological_Examination.Meningeal_Signs: Marked nuchal rigidity. Positive Kernig's sign bilaterally. Positive Brudzinski's sign.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Head_and_Neck: No signs of head trauma. No sinus tenderness. Oropharynx clear. Tympanic membranes normal.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Cardiovascular_Examination: Tachycardic, regular rhythm. S1, S2 normal. No murmurs, rubs, or gallops.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Respiratory_Examination: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes or crackles.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Abdominal_Examination: Soft, non-tender, non-distended. Bowel sounds present and normal. No hepatosplenomegaly.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Dermatological_Examination: No petechiae, purpura, or other rashes noted. Skin warm and dry.

CT_Brain_Non-Contrast.Reason_for_Scan: Altered mental status (GCS 14) prior to lumbar puncture.
CT_Brain_Non-Contrast.Findings: No evidence of acute intracranial hemorrhage, mass effect, hydrocephalus, or significant cerebral edema. Grey-white matter differentiation is preserved. Ventricles and basal cisterns appear normal. No signs of skull fracture.

Lumbar_Puncture_and_CSF_Analysis.Glucose: 1.2 mmol/L (markedly low; corresponding serum glucose 6.0 mmol/L, CSF/serum ratio ~0.2)
Lumbar_Puncture_and_CSF_Analysis.Gram_Stain: Numerous Gram-positive cocci in pairs and short chains identified.
Lumbar_Puncture_and_CSF_Analysis.CSF_PCR_Panel_for_Meningitis/Encephaliti: Pending (includes S. pneumoniae, N. meningitidis, H. influenzae, Listeria, HSV, VZV, Enterovirus)

Chest_X-Ray_PA_and_Lateral.Findings: Lungs are clear. No focal consolidation, effusion or pneumothorax. Cardiomediastinal silhouette is normal.

Other_Tests.Urine_Dipstick: Negative for leukocytes, nitrites, blood, protein, glucose.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Bacterial Meningitis (likely Pneumococcal Meningitis based on Gram stain)

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess, diagnose, and formulate an initial management plan for a patient presenting with recurrent severe headaches.

Patient_Actor.History: Patient presents with a 12-hour history of severe left-sided headache. She reports experiencing similar headaches recurrently for the past 5 years, occurring 1-2 times per month, but this episode is one of the most severe. She describes the pain as throbbing, rated 8/10 in intensity. The headache was preceded by approximately 20 minutes of seeing flashing zigzag lines in her right visual field. She feels nauseous and has vomited once. She is sensitive to light and sound, preferring to be in a dark, quiet room. Physical activity, like walking, significantly worsens the pain. She identifies stress from work deadlines and sometimes her menstrual cycle as potential triggers. Over-the-counter analgesics (ibuprofen 400mg, paracetamol 1000mg) have provided minimal relief for this episode. She has a past medical history of Generalized Anxiety Disorder, well-controlled with an SSRI. Her mother also suffers from 'bad headaches,' diagnosed as migraines.
Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD), diagnosed 2 years ago, managed with Escitalopram 10mg daily. No history of head trauma, seizures, or stroke. Childhood asthma, infrequent inhaler use. Takes combined oral contraceptive pill.
Patient_Actor.Family_History: Mother has migraines. Father has hypertension. No family history of brain aneurysms or tumors explicitly mentioned, but patient expresses some anxiety about 'something serious' due to headache severity.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Works as a graphic designer, often long hours on the computer. Non-smoker. Drinks 2-3 units of alcohol per week, notes red wine can occasionally trigger headaches. Reports good sleep hygiene generally, but has been more stressed recently due to work.

Review_of_Systems.General: Denies fever, chills, unexplained weight loss, night sweats.
Review_of_Systems.Neurological: Denies persistent focal weakness, numbness, paresthesias (other than transient aura symptoms which have resolved), diplopia (other than shimmering during aura), dysarthria, ataxia (outside of acute headache episode where movement is difficult), seizures, loss of consciousness. Denies changes in cognition or memory. Denies recent head injury.
Review_of_Systems.HEENT: Denies vision loss (other than aura), persistent eye pain, ear discharge, sinus pressure/pain, purulent nasal discharge, sore throat, jaw claudication, scalp tenderness.
Review_of_Systems.Neck: Reports some mild neck stiffness/discomfort associated with the headache, but denies true nuchal rigidity preventing neck flexion. Denies radiation of pain into arms.
Review_of_Systems.Gastrointestinal: Nausea and one episode of vomiting with current headache. Denies abdominal pain, diarrhea, constipation.
Review_of_Systems.Musculoskeletal: Denies generalized joint pain or swelling.

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Patient appears uncomfortable, lying still on the examination couch, shielding eyes from ambient light. Cooperative but visibly distressed by pain.

HEENT.Head: Normocephalic, atraumatic. No signs of trauma.
HEENT.Eyes: Pupils equal, round, and reactive to light and accommodation (PERRLA). Conjunctivae clear, no scleral icterus. Extraocular movements intact and pain-free. Fundoscopy: Optic discs sharp, margins clear, no papilledema, no hemorrhages or exudates. Visual fields full to confrontation (aura symptoms have resolved).
HEENT.Ears: External auditory canals clear, tympanic membranes normal bilaterally.
HEENT.Nose: No nasal discharge, mucosa non-inflamed. No tenderness on palpation over frontal or maxillary sinuses.
HEENT.Throat: Oropharynx clear, no erythema or exudate.
HEENT.Temporal_Arteries: Non-tender to palpation, normal pulsation, no induration.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Neck: Supple range of motion in all directions, though patient reports mild discomfort at extremes of flexion. No nuchal rigidity (Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs negative). No cervical lymphadenopathy. Mild tenderness to palpation of posterior cervical paraspinal muscles bilaterally.

Neurological_Examination.Mental_Status: Alert, oriented to person, place, and time (A&O x3). Speech is clear and coherent. Appears anxious due to pain.
Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves_II-XII: Intact. (Visual acuity grossly normal post-aura, fields full as above. Facial sensation and movement symmetrical. Hearing grossly intact. Gag reflex present. Tongue midline, shoulder shrug symmetrical).
Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Normal muscle bulk and tone. Power 5/5 in all four limbs proximally and distally. No pronator drift.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Intact to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception in all four limbs. No sensory level.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Deep tendon reflexes 2+ and symmetrical throughout (biceps, triceps, brachioradialis, patellar, Achilles). Plantar reflexes downgoing bilaterally.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar_Function: Finger-nose-finger and heel-to-shin tests performed accurately, though patient moves slowly and cautiously due to headache. No dysmetria or intention tremor. No dysdiadochokinesia. Romberg test negative (patient able to stand with minimal sway, eyes open and closed).
Neurological_Examination.Gait: Observed walking a few steps to the examination couch; gait was slow and cautious due to pain, but no ataxia, wide base, or focal deficit noted.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Cardiovascular_Examination: Regular rate and rhythm. Normal S1 and S2. No murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Peripheral pulses palpable and symmetrical.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Respiratory_Examination: Chest clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, crackles, or rhonchi. Respiratory effort non-labored.

CT_Brain_Non-Contrast.Reason_for_ordering: Patient presenting with one of her most severe headaches, associated visual aura, and significant distress/anxiety. To rule out acute intracranial pathology such as hemorrhage, mass lesion, or other structural abnormality, particularly given patient anxiety.
CT_Brain_Non-Contrast.Findings: No evidence of acute intracranial hemorrhage, space-occupying lesion, hydrocephalus, or acute territorial infarct. Ventricular system and sulci are normal for age. Paranasal sinuses and mastoid air cells are clear. No bony abnormality identified.

Other_Tests_Considered_but_not_immediate.MRI_Brain_MRA_Brain: May be considered if headaches become refractory to standard migraine treatment, change significantly in character, or if new neurological signs or symptoms develop. MRA could be considered if there was higher suspicion for vascular anomaly, but CT was reassuring for acute bleed.
Other_Tests_Considered_but_not_immediate.Lumbar_Puncture: Not indicated in the absence of fever, confirmed nuchal rigidity, or persistent suspicion of subarachnoid hemorrhage with a negative CT scan (especially if CT performed >6-12 hours post-onset, though current CT was timely).

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Migraine with aura

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose an elderly patient presenting with chronic headaches and hearing loss.

Patient_Actor.History: Patient reports a 9-month history of progressively worsening headaches, described as a deep, aching pain, predominantly over the frontal and parietal regions of his skull. He also notes that his hats have become tighter over the past year and has experienced a gradual decline in his hearing, particularly in his right ear. The headache is often worse at night and with head movement. Over-the-counter analgesics (ibuprofen, paracetamol) provide only minimal and temporary relief.

Secondary_Symptoms: Gradual hearing loss (right ear > left ear)
Occasional warmth felt over the scalp

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Hypertension, well-controlled on Lisinopril. Osteoarthritis of the knees diagnosed 5 years ago. No history of malignancy, head trauma, or previous significant neurological illness. Denies previous fractures.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Retired school teacher. Non-smoker, drinks alcohol socially (2-3 units per week). Lives with his wife. Reports a maternal aunt had 'brittle bones' and hearing problems in old age.

Review_of_Systems.General: Denies fever, chills, night sweats, or unintentional weight loss.
Review_of_Systems.HEENT: Besides headache and hearing loss, denies visual disturbances (blurring, diplopia, floaters), tinnitus, dizziness, vertigo, jaw claudication, scalp tenderness, sore throat, or nasal congestion/discharge.
Review_of_Systems.Neurological: Denies focal weakness, numbness, paresthesias, seizures, syncope, changes in speech, coordination problems, or gait disturbance.
Review_of_Systems.Musculoskeletal: Reports existing bilateral knee pain consistent with osteoarthritis. Denies recent onset of pain in other bones or joints. Denies back pain.
Review_of_Systems.Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, change in bowel habits.

General_Examination.Appearance: Appears well, in no acute distress. Alert and oriented x3.
General_Examination.Skull: Mild frontal bossing noted. Palpable warmth and slight tenderness over the right parietal bone. No visible scalp lesions.

HEENT_Examination.Head: Normocephalic with slight asymmetry due to frontal bossing.
HEENT_Examination.Eyes: PERRLA. Extraocular movements intact. Visual acuity 20/20 bilaterally with correction. Fundoscopy: Optic discs sharp, no papilledema, normal vasculature.
HEENT_Examination.Ears: Otoscopy: External auditory canals and tympanic membranes normal bilaterally. Whispered voice test: Reduced hearing in right ear. Weber test: Lateralizes to the left ear. Rinne test: AC > BC bilaterally, but AC reduced on the right compared to left, suggesting right sensorineural hearing loss.
HEENT_Examination.Nose: No deformities, septum midline, mucosa normal.
HEENT_Examination.Neck: Supple, no lymphadenopathy, no thyromegaly. Carotid pulses normal, no bruits.
HEENT_Examination.Temporal_Arteries: Palpable, non-tender, no thickening or reduced pulsation.

Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: CN I: Not tested. CN II: Acuity and fields normal, fundi normal. CN III, IV, VI: EOMs full, no nystagmus, pupils reactive. CN V: Facial sensation intact, motor function normal. CN VII: Facial movements symmetrical. CN VIII: Decreased hearing on the right (as above). CN IX, X: Gag reflex present, uvula midline. CN XI: Shoulder shrug and head turn normal strength. CN XII: Tongue midline, no fasciculations.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Normal tone, bulk, and power (5/5) in all four limbs.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Intact to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception in all limbs.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Deep tendon reflexes 2+ and symmetrical throughout. Plantar responses flexor bilaterally.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar_Function: Finger-nose, heel-shin tests normal. No dysdiadochokinesia. Gait normal, Romberg negative.

Musculoskeletal_Examination.Findings: No deformities or tenderness over long bones or spine. Range of motion in peripheral joints (excluding knees) full and painless. Knees: Mild crepitus bilaterally, no acute inflammation.

Skull_X-ray.Findings: Diffuse skull thickening, particularly of the calvarium. Areas of mixed osteolytic and osteosclerotic changes, giving a 'cotton wool' appearance. Possible basilar invagination.

CT_Brain_without_contrast.Findings: No acute intracranial hemorrhage, mass effect, or hydrocephalus. Significant thickening and sclerosis of the calvarium and skull base consistent with Paget disease. No acute infarct.

Radionuclide_Bone_Scan_Whole_Body.Findings: Intense increased tracer uptake in the skull (calvarium and base), pelvis (right ilium and ischium), and proximal right femur. Pattern highly suggestive of polyostotic Paget disease of bone.

Audiometry.Findings: Moderate sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear. Mild sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Paget disease of bone (osteitis deformans) affecting the skull, pelvis, and femur, causing headache and hearing loss.

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose a patient presenting with chronic headaches, visual changes, and menstrual irregularities.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient reports a 6-month history of progressively worsening headaches, primarily located behind the eyes and across the forehead. Initially intermittent, they are now almost daily and partially relieved by over-the-counter analgesics. Over the past 3 months, she has noticed 'clumsiness', often bumping into objects on her sides, and difficulty with peripheral vision, especially when driving. She also reports amenorrhea for the last 4 months, which she attributed to work stress. She feels increasingly fatigued despite adequate sleep.
Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Migraines in adolescence, resolved in early 20s. No other significant medical history. No previous surgeries. Vaccinations up to date.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Works as a marketing executive, reports high work-related stress. Non-smoker, drinks 2-3 glasses of wine per week. Denies illicit drug use. Lives with her partner.
Medications: Ibuprofen 400mg as needed for headaches (taken 3-4 times a week)

Review_of_Systems.General: Fatigue reported. No fever, chills, or recent weight loss (weight stable).
Review_of_Systems.HEENT: Headache as described. Describes vision as 'blurry on the sides'. Denies diplopia, photophobia, phonophobia, eye pain, or discharge. Denies nasal congestion, sore throat, or earache.
Review_of_Systems.Neurological: Denies seizures, syncope, focal weakness, numbness (other than visual), or speech difficulties. Denies vertigo or tinnitus.
Review_of_Systems.Endocrine: Amenorrhea for 4 months. Denies galactorrhea, polyuria, polydipsia, heat or cold intolerance. No changes in shoe or ring size.
Review_of_Systems.Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea, vomiting, changes in bowel habits.
Review_of_Systems.Musculoskeletal: Denies joint pain or muscle weakness.

General_Examination.Appearance: Appears tired but in no acute distress. Well-nourished. No acromegalic or Cushingoid features.

Neurological_Examination.Mental_Status: Alert, oriented to time, place, and person. Speech is clear and fluent.

Cranial_Nerves.CN_I_Olfactory: Not formally tested, patient reports normal sense of smell.
Cranial_Nerves.CN_II_Optic: Visual acuity 6/9 bilaterally with correction. Visual fields by confrontation reveal bitemporal hemianopia. Fundoscopy shows sharp optic disc margins bilaterally, no papilledema, no hemorrhages. Mild temporal pallor of optic discs noted.
Cranial_Nerves.CN_III_Oculomotor_IV_Trochlear_VI_Abduce: Pupils equal, round, reactive to light and accommodation (PERRLA). Extraocular movements full in all directions, no nystagmus, no ptosis.
Cranial_Nerves.CN_V_Trigeminal: Facial sensation intact to light touch and pinprick in all three divisions bilaterally. Motor function (muscles of mastication) normal.
Cranial_Nerves.CN_VIII_Vestibulocochlear: Hearing grossly intact to whispered voice bilaterally. Weber and Rinne tests normal.
Cranial_Nerves.CN_IX_Glossopharyngeal_X_Vagus: Gag reflex present, uvula midline, palate elevates symmetrically.
Cranial_Nerves.CN_XI_Accessory: Shoulder shrug and head turn against resistance normal.
Cranial_Nerves.CN_XII_Hypoglossal: Tongue protrudes midline, no fasciculations or atrophy.

Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Normal muscle bulk, tone, and power (5/5) in all four limbs. No abnormal movements.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Intact to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception in all limbs.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Deep tendon reflexes 2+ and symmetrical throughout. Plantar reflexes downgoing bilaterally.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar_Function: Finger-nose and heel-shin tests performed well. No dysmetria or dysdiadochokinesia.
Neurological_Examination.Gait: Normal gait and station. Romberg test negative.
Neurological_Examination.Meningeal_Signs: No neck stiffness. Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs negative.

Endocrine_Examination.Breast: No spontaneous galactorrhea. On gentle expression, a small drop of milky discharge noted from right nipple (pertinent positive).
Endocrine_Examination.Skin: No striae, hirsutism, or acanthosis nigricans.

Endocrine_Profile.TSH: 1.2 mIU/L (Reference range 0.4-4.0 mIU/L) - Inappropriately normal for low T4
Endocrine_Profile.LH: 1.5 IU/L (Reference range follicular phase 2-10 IU/L) - Low
Endocrine_Profile.FSH: 2.0 IU/L (Reference range follicular phase 3-10 IU/L) - Low
Endocrine_Profile.Estradiol: 50 pmol/L (Reference range follicular phase 70-550 pmol/L) - Low
Endocrine_Profile.Cortisol_8AM: 180 nmol/L (Reference range 170-540 nmol/L) - Low normal, warrants further investigation (e.g. Synacthen test)
Endocrine_Profile.ACTH_8AM: 3.0 pmol/L (Reference range 2-11 pmol/L) - Inappropriately low/normal for cortisol level
Endocrine_Profile.IGF-1: Normal for age and sex (rules out acromegaly)

MRI_Brain_with_pituitary_protocol_with_a.Findings: A 1.8 x 1.5 x 1.3 cm sellar mass consistent with a pituitary macroadenoma, demonstrating homogenous enhancement post-contrast. The adenoma extends superiorly, compressing and superiorly displacing the optic chiasm. The pituitary stalk is deviated. No evidence of hemorrhage or cystic change within the adenoma. Remainder of brain parenchyma unremarkable.

Formal_Visual_Field_Testing_Humphrey.Findings: Bitemporal superior quadrantanopia, progressing to near complete bitemporal hemianopia in the inferior fields.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Pituitary macroadenoma (likely prolactinoma) causing compression of the optic chiasm, secondary hypogonadism, and secondary hypothyroidism.

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose a patient presenting with persistent headaches and cognitive symptoms following a head injury.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient reports sustaining a head injury during a rugby match approximately 3 weeks ago. He states he was tackled and his head hit the ground. He did not lose consciousness but felt 'dazed' and 'saw stars' for a few minutes. He was removed from the game. Headaches began the following day and have been persistent. He is concerned as his symptoms are affecting his studies and daily life.

Secondary_Symptoms: Intermittent dizziness, especially with quick head movements

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: One previous mild concussion 2 years ago during a football game, with symptoms resolving completely within one week. No history of migraines or other headache disorders. No known neurological or psychiatric conditions. Vaccinations up to date.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: University student studying engineering. Lives in a student dormitory. Reports feeling stressed about upcoming exams. Drinks 2-3 beers on weekend nights, denies smoking or illicit drug use. Active in university rugby team.
Patient_Actor.Medications: Occasional ibuprofen for headache, provides minimal relief. No regular medications.

Review_of_Systems.Neurological: Headache is bifrontal, described as a dull ache with intermittent throbbing, rated 5-7/10, worse with prolonged mental effort (e.g., studying) and towards the end of the day. Denies seizures, focal weakness, numbness, tingling, frank vertigo, or syncope. Reports some 'eye strain' when reading for long periods.
Review_of_Systems.HEENT: Denies visual loss, diplopia (other than 'eye strain'), ear pain, tinnitus (other than occasional brief ringing), sore throat, or nasal discharge. Had some neck soreness immediately after the injury which has mostly resolved.
Review_of_Systems.Gastrointestinal: Reports one episode of nausea immediately after the injury, but no vomiting since. Denies abdominal pain, changes in bowel habits.
Review_of_Systems.Musculoskeletal: Mild residual neck stiffness but no significant pain. Denies other joint or muscle pain.
Review_of_Systems.Psychiatric: Reports feeling more irritable and easily frustrated. Denies persistent low mood or anhedonia prior to injury, but feeling down due to ongoing symptoms.
Review_of_Systems.Integumentary: Denies rashes or bruising (other than initial scalp soreness which resolved).
Review_of_Systems.Endocrine: Denies polyuria, polydipsia, heat or cold intolerance.

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Alert, oriented to person, place, time, and situation. Appears somewhat fatigued and expresses frustration with his symptoms. Cooperative with examination.

Head_and_Neck_Examination.Head: Normocephalic, atraumatic. No scalp tenderness, swelling, or deformities noted.
Head_and_Neck_Examination.Neck: Supple. Full range of motion, though reports mild discomfort at extremes of lateral flexion and rotation. No cervical lymphadenopathy. No carotid bruits. No signs of meningeal irritation (Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs negative).

Neurological_Examination.Mental_Status: Alert and oriented x4. Speech is clear and fluent. Attention and concentration: Able to perform serial 7s with some hesitation, makes one error. Recall: 2/3 objects after 5 minutes. Mood appears euthymic but reports irritability. Affect congruent with mood.
Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: CN I (Olfactory): Not tested. CN II (Optic): Visual acuity grossly normal with correction (patient wears glasses for reading). Visual fields full to confrontation. Fundoscopy: Optic discs sharp, no hemorrhages, exudates, or papilledema. CN III, IV, VI (Oculomotor, Trochlear, Abducens): Pupils equal (3mm), round, and reactive to light and accommodation. Extraocular movements intact, no nystagmus. No ptosis. CN V (Trigeminal): Sensation intact in all three divisions bilaterally. Motor function (muscles of mastication) normal. Corneal reflex not tested. CN VII (Facial): Facial movements symmetric, no weakness. CN VIII (Vestibulocochlear): Hearing grossly intact to whispered voice bilaterally. Weber test midline. Rinne AC > BC bilaterally. CN IX, X (Glossopharyngeal, Vagus): Gag reflex present (not elicited), uvula midline, palate elevates symmetrically. CN XI (Accessory): Shoulder shrug and head turn against resistance normal. CN XII (Hypoglossal): Tongue protrudes midline, no fasciculations or atrophy.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Bulk, tone, and power (5/5) normal in all four limbs. No pronator drift. No tremors or involuntary movements.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Intact to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception in all four limbs.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Deep tendon reflexes 2+ and symmetrical throughout (biceps, triceps, brachioradialis, patellar, Achilles). Plantar reflexes downgoing bilaterally.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar_Function: Finger-to-nose and heel-to-shin tests performed well bilaterally. Rapid alternating movements normal. Romberg test: Negative (stable with eyes open and closed).
Neurological_Examination.Gait: Normal gait base and stride. Able to walk on heels and toes. Tandem gait performed with mild unsteadiness (a few missteps, but does not fall).

Physical_Examination_Findings.Cardiovascular_Examination: Regular rate and rhythm, S1S2 normal, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Respiratory_Examination: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes or crackles.

CT_Brain_without_contrast.Findings: No evidence of acute intracranial hemorrhage, mass effect, midline shift, or skull fracture. Ventricles and sulci are normal for age.

MRI_Brain_without_contrast_and_with_SWI_.Findings: No evidence of acute or subacute intracranial hemorrhage, space-occupying lesion, restricted diffusion, or abnormal enhancement. Ventricular system and basal cisterns are unremarkable. Susceptibility Weighted Imaging (SWI) shows no evidence of microhemorrhages. Grey-white matter differentiation is preserved. No evidence of hydrocephalus or cerebral edema.

Standardized_Assessment_of_Concussion_SA.Score_on_sideline_post_injury: Not formally performed, patient reported feeling 'dazed'.
Standardized_Assessment_of_Concussion_SA.Score_today_if_performed: Would likely show deficits in concentration and delayed recall consistent with mental status exam.

Vision_Assessment_Optometry_Referral.Findings: Patient referred due to photophobia and eye strain. Report indicates mild convergence insufficiency and accommodative dysfunction. No acute ocular pathology.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Post-concussion headache (part of Post-Concussion Syndrome)

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose a 28-year-old post-partum female presenting with a severe headache.

Patient_Actor.Demographics: 28-year-old female, G1P1, 3 days post-partum via spontaneous vaginal delivery.
Patient_Actor.History: Patient presents with a severe headache that started approximately 24 hours after an epidural catheter was placed for labor analgesia. The delivery was uncomplicated. The headache is described as throbbing, primarily occipital and frontal, rated 9/10 in severity. It is significantly worse when she sits or stands up, and almost completely relieved by lying flat. She has associated nausea and some photophobia and phonophobia. She denies any prior history of similar headaches or migraines.
Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: G1P1, uncomplicated pregnancy. Epidural analgesia during labor 3 days ago. No history of migraines, clotting disorders, or previous significant headaches. No known drug allergies.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Non-smoker, denies alcohol use (especially post-partum). Lives with her husband, supportive home environment. Currently on maternity leave.

Review_of_Systems.General: Fatigue, attributed to new motherhood and pain.
Review_of_Systems.Neurological: Headache as described. Denies focal weakness, numbness, tingling, seizures, visual disturbances (other than photophobia), or speech changes. Denies fever or chills.
Review_of_Systems.Gastrointestinal: Nausea present. No vomiting. Normal bowel movements.
Review_of_Systems.Genitourinary: Normal lochia. Denies dysuria or urinary retention.
Review_of_Systems.Musculoskeletal: Mild neck stiffness. No other joint or muscle pain. Epidural site slightly tender but no redness or discharge.

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Patient appears uncomfortable, lying flat on the bed. Prefers dim lighting.

Neurological_Examination.Mental_Status: Alert, oriented to time, place, and person. Glasgow Coma Scale 15/15.
Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: Pupils equal, round, reactive to light and accommodation. Fundoscopy: Optic discs sharp, no papilledema. Visual fields full to confrontation. Extraocular movements intact, no nystagmus, no diplopia. Facial sensation and power normal. Hearing grossly intact.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Normal tone, bulk, and power (5/5) in all four limbs. Deep tendon reflexes 2+ and symmetrical.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Intact to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception throughout.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar_Function: Finger-nose-finger and heel-shin tests normal when patient briefly sits up with assistance, though this exacerbates headache.
Neurological_Examination.Gait: Not formally assessed due to severe exacerbation of headache on attempting to stand.
Neurological_Examination.Meningeal_Signs: Mild neck stiffness on forward flexion, attributed by patient to pain. Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs negative.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Cardiovascular_Examination: Heart sounds S1, S2 normal, no murmurs.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Abdominal_Examination: Soft, non-tender, bowel sounds present. Uterus involuting appropriately for post-partum day 3.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Back_Examination: Epidural insertion site: Clean, dry, intact. Mild tenderness on palpation over L3/L4 interspace, no erythema, warmth, swelling, or discharge.

Urine_Analysis.Dipstick: No protein, no ketones, no glucose, no blood, no nitrites, no leukocytes.

CT_Brain_without_contrast.Reason_for_ordering: Rule out acute intracranial hemorrhage, stroke, or space-occupying lesion given severity of headache.
CT_Brain_without_contrast.Findings: No evidence of acute intracranial hemorrhage, mass effect, midline shift, or hydrocephalus. Ventricles and sulci appear normal.

MRI_Brain_with_and_without_gadolinium_co.Reason_for_ordering: Further evaluation of persistent severe headache with postural component, normal CT, to assess for signs of intracranial hypotension or other pathologies like CVT.
MRI_Brain_with_and_without_gadolinium_co.Findings: Diffuse pachymeningeal (dural) enhancement present. Mild sagging of the cerebellar tonsils (2mm below foramen magnum). No evidence of venous sinus thrombosis, infarct, tumor, or hydrocephalus. Subdural fluid collections are absent. Pituitary gland appears normal in size.

Other_Investigations.Lumbar_Puncture: Not performed. Contraindicated due to high clinical suspicion of post-dural puncture headache, as it could worsen the CSF leak. Clinical and imaging findings consistent with PDPH.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Post-epidural headache (Post-dural puncture headache)

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose a patient presenting with a severe headache following a recent medical procedure.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents to the emergency department with a severe headache that started two days ago. She describes the headache as throbbing, located primarily in the occipital region and radiating to the frontal area. The headache is significantly worse when she sits or stands up (rated 8/10), and almost completely resolves when she lies flat (rated 1-2/10). She underwent a lumbar puncture three days ago in the neurology clinic to investigate a brief episode of unexplained fever and neck stiffness, which had resolved prior to the LP. The LP results were reportedly normal. She feels nauseous and has vomited twice today. She also mentions some mild neck discomfort and sensitivity to light.
