Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Generally healthy. No history of migraines or chronic headaches. Lumbar puncture 3 days prior for investigation of transient fever and neck stiffness (initial CSF results were normal).

Medications_Allergies.Medications: Occasional paracetamol for mild headaches (ineffective for current headache).

Patient_Actor.Social_History: Works as a graphic designer. Non-smoker, drinks alcohol socially (1-2 glasses of wine per week).

Review_of_Systems.General: Denies fever, chills, or weight loss since the LP. Reports some fatigue likely due to poor sleep from headache.
Review_of_Systems.Neurological: Headache is 8/10 when upright, 1-2/10 when supine. Denies focal weakness, numbness, paraesthesia, diplopia, blurred vision (other than general photophobia), seizures, changes in speech, or new problems with coordination. Denies tinnitus or significant hearing loss. Denies preceding aura.
Review_of_Systems.ENT: Denies ear discharge or severe vertigo.
Review_of_Systems.MSK: Mild neck discomfort, worse with upright posture, but denies significant neck rigidity preventing flexion. No other joint or muscle pain.
Review_of_Systems.Respiratory: Denies cough or shortness of breath.
Review_of_Systems.GI: Nausea and two episodes of non-bloody, non-bilious vomiting today. Denies abdominal pain, diarrhea, or constipation.

Vital_Signs.Blood_Pressure: 118/75 mmHg (supine), 115/72 mmHg (standing, after 1 min, patient reports significant worsening of headache and requests to lie down)

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Appears uncomfortable and pale, prefers to lie flat on the examination couch with eyes closed. Well-nourished and well-hydrated.

Neurological_Examination.Mental_Status: Alert, awake, and oriented to person, place, and time (GCS 15/15). Speech is clear and coherent.
Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: II-XII intact. Pupils 3mm, equal, round, and briskly reactive to light and accommodation. Fundoscopy: Optic discs sharp with clear margins, no hemorrhages, exudates, or papilledema. Visual fields full to confrontation. Extraocular movements intact, no nystagmus. Facial sensation and movement symmetrical. Hearing grossly intact bilaterally (Weber midline, Rinne AC>BC).
Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Normal tone and bulk. Power 5/5 in all four limbs (upper and lower). No pronator drift.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Deep tendon reflexes 2+ and symmetrical throughout (biceps, triceps, brachioradialis, patellar, Achilles). Plantar reflexes downgoing bilaterally.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Intact to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception in all limbs.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar_Function: Finger-nose-finger and heel-shin tests performed accurately and smoothly when patient is supine. Gait not formally assessed due to severe postural exacerbation of headache, but patient reports no issues with balance when headache is minimal (supine). Romberg test negative (performed briefly while sitting).
Neurological_Examination.Meningeal_Signs: No nuchal rigidity (neck supple with full range of passive flexion when supine without significant pain). Kernig's sign negative. Brudzinski's sign negative.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Spinal_Examination: Lumbar puncture site inspected in the L3-L4 interspace: Clean, dry, and intact. No erythema, swelling, tenderness, fluctuance, or discharge.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Cardiovascular_Examination: Regular rhythm. Heart sounds S1, S2 normal, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Respiratory_Examination: Chest clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes or crackles. Good air entry.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Abdominal_Examination: Soft, non-tender, non-distended. Normoactive bowel sounds. No organomegaly or masses palpated.

Previous_LP_Details.Indication: Investigation of transient fever (38.5°C) and neck stiffness 4 days prior to current presentation (symptoms had resolved by time of LP). Suspected meningitis.
Previous_LP_Details.Needle_Type_Size: 22-gauge Quincke cutting spinal needle (confirmed from procedure note).

CSF_Analysis_Results_from_LP.Bacterial_Culture: No growth at 48 hours (final result pending but unlikely to be positive).

CT_Brain_Non_Contrast.Reason_for_ordering: Rule out acute intracranial hemorrhage, space-occupying lesion, or hydrocephalus given severity of new-onset headache.
CT_Brain_Non_Contrast.Findings: No evidence of acute intracranial hemorrhage, mass effect, midline shift, or hydrocephalus. Ventricular system and sulci are normal in size and appearance. Grey-white matter differentiation is preserved. Basal cisterns are patent. No signs of sinus thrombosis visible on non-contrast study.

MRI_Brain_with_and_without_Gadolinium_Co.Reason_for_ordering: To investigate persistent severe postural headache, highly suspicious for post-lumbar puncture headache, and to rule out other less likely pathologies. Specifically looking for signs of intracranial hypotension.
MRI_Brain_with_and_without_Gadolinium_Co.Findings: Diffuse, smooth pachymeningeal (dural) enhancement observed post-gadolinium administration throughout the supratentorial and infratentorial compartments. Mild sagging of the cerebellar tonsils, extending approximately 2mm below the foramen magnum (borderline Chiari I malformation not previously known, but likely incidental or exacerbated by low pressure). Ventricles are normal to small in size. No subdural fluid collections or hygromas. Pituitary gland appears mildly enlarged and hyperemic. Findings are highly consistent with intracranial hypotension, likely secondary to CSF leakage post-lumbar puncture.

Differential_Diagnosis_Considerations: Meningitis (bacterial, viral, or aseptic - largely ruled out by previous LP results, current afebrile state, negative inflammatory markers, and negative meningeal signs)
Subarachnoid hemorrhage (ruled out by normal CT brain)
Migraine with new onset or atypical features (postural component less typical for primary migraine)
Cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (CVST - low pretest probability, non-contrast CT not definitive but no gross signs, MRI/MRV would be more specific if high suspicion)
Spontaneous intracranial hypotension (less likely given clear temporal relationship to LP)
Tension-type headache (postural nature and severity atypical)
Cervicogenic headache (less likely to have such a strong postural component and associated nausea/photophobia)
OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Post-lumbar puncture headache

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose a patient presenting with recurrent severe headaches exclusively associated with sexual activity.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient reports three episodes of sudden, severe headache in the past month. Each episode occurred exclusively during sexual activity, starting abruptly at the point of orgasm. He describes the headache as 'explosive' and 'the worst I've felt initially'. The pain is bilateral, predominantly occipital and throbbing, lasting for approximately 1 to 2 hours before gradually subsiding. He has not experienced such headaches outside of this context. He has a history of occasional migraines (1-2 times per year, typically preceded by visual aura and unilateral, which feels different from these current headaches). He is worried and initially hesitant to discuss the specific trigger. He has tried over-the-counter ibuprofen with minimal relief for these headaches.
Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Migraine with aura (diagnosed 5 years ago, infrequent episodes, last one 6 months ago). No history of hypertension, stroke, aneurysm, or head trauma. Vaccinations up to date.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Works as an accountant, reports increased work stress over the past two months. Married, in a monogamous relationship. Consumes 2-3 units of alcohol per week. Non-smoker. Denies illicit drug use, including cocaine or amphetamines.
Medications: Sumatriptan as needed for typical migraines (not used for these new headaches)
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Reports some anxiety regarding these headaches. Denies fever, chills, weight loss, or night sweats. No preceding aura with these specific headaches. No focal neurological deficits such as weakness, numbness, visual loss (other than photophobia), diplopia, or speech difficulties before, during, or after the headaches. No loss of consciousness. No neck stiffness preceding the headache, though reports some tension in neck muscles during the peak of the headache. No jaw claudication or scalp tenderness. No change in bowel or bladder habits. No rash.

Vital_Signs.Blood_Pressure: 142/88 mmHg (on arrival), rechecked after 30 mins: 125/78 mmHg

General_Examination.Appearance: Alert, anxious but cooperative.

Neurological_Examination.Mental_Status: Alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Speech fluent.
Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: II-XII grossly intact. Pupils equal, round, and reactive to light and accommodation (PERRLA). Visual fields full to confrontation. Fundoscopy reveals sharp optic discs bilaterally, no papilledema, hemorrhages, or exudates.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Normal muscle bulk, tone, and power (5/5) in all four limbs. No pronator drift.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Deep tendon reflexes 2+ and symmetrical throughout.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Intact to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception in all extremities.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar_Function: Finger-to-nose and heel-to-shin tests performed well. No dysdiadochokinesia. Romberg's test negative.
Neurological_Examination.Gait: Normal gait, able to tandem walk.
Neurological_Examination.Meningeal_Signs: Neck supple. Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs negative.

Cardiovascular_Examination.Heart_Sounds: S1 and S2 normal, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops.

Respiratory_Examination.Auscultation: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes or crackles.

CT_Brain_Non_Contrast.Findings: No evidence of acute intracranial hemorrhage, mass effect, edema, or territorial infarction. Ventricular system and basal cisterns are normal.

MRI_Brain_with_MRA_Head.MRI_Findings: Normal brain parenchyma. No evidence of acute ischemia, hemorrhage, tumor, or hydrocephalus. No abnormal signal changes in sulci or basal cisterns to suggest subarachnoid blood. No signs of reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome (RCVS).
MRI_Brain_with_MRA_Head.MRA_Head_Findings: Patent major intracranial arteries and venous sinuses. No evidence of aneurysm, arteriovenous malformation, stenosis, or dissection.

Lumbar_Puncture.Indication: Performed due to the thunderclap onset of headaches to definitively rule out subarachnoid hemorrhage not visible on CT.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Primary Headache Associated with Sexual Activity (Postcoital Headache)

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess a patient with chronic daily headaches, evaluate potential organic causes, consider psychosocial factors, and formulate a diagnosis and initial management plan.

Patient_Actor.History: Ms. Sarah Miller presents with a 6-month history of persistent headaches. The headaches started gradually but have significantly worsened over the past 3 months, coinciding with her being laid off from her job. She describes the headache as being present 'all the time, every day.' She is very worried she might have a serious underlying condition like a brain tumor. She has seen two other doctors and a chiropractor previously, with no definitive diagnosis or relief.

Secondary_Symptoms: Intermittent blurred vision, lasting a few minutes, especially when stressed (ophthalmology review was normal)

Headache_Characteristics.Onset: Gradual over 6 months, worsened significantly 3 months ago
Headache_Characteristics.Location: Variable; sometimes 'all over my head', sometimes 'like a tight band', other times 'a crushing pressure behind my eyes', or 'sharp stabbing pains that move around'
Headache_Characteristics.Severity: Rates it 8-10/10 on most days, but can carry on conversations and activities with some effort
Headache_Characteristics.Aggravating_Factors: Stress, thinking about problems, sometimes noise or bright lights (inconsistently)
Headache_Characteristics.Relieving_Factors: No consistent relieving factors. 'Sometimes lying in a dark room helps a bit, sometimes it doesn't.'
Headache_Characteristics.Associated_Symptoms_Specific_to_Headache: Reports no consistent aura, nausea, or vomiting directly with the headache, unless she 'worries herself sick about it'. Inconsistent mild photophobia/phonophobia.

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Mild intermittent asthma, well-controlled (uses salbutamol inhaler rarely, last used >6 months ago). Minor whiplash injury from a low-speed car accident 1 year ago, neck pain resolved within a few weeks with physiotherapy; she wonders if this could be related. No history of migraines or other significant neurological conditions.
Medications: Paracetamol (acetaminophen) 1g up to QDS - 'doesn't touch it'
Occasional codeine (from an old prescription for a dental issue) - 'makes me drowsy but headache remains'
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Recently laid off from her job as an administrative assistant 3 months ago, currently unemployed and experiencing significant financial stress. Lives with her partner; reports increased tension in the relationship due to financial worries. Denies smoking or illicit drug use. Drinks 1-2 glasses of wine on weekends. Reports poor sleep quality, difficulty falling asleep due to 'racing thoughts' and worry about her health and future.
Patient_Actor.Family_History: Mother has episodic migraines. Father has hypertension. No family history of brain tumors, aneurysms, or other severe neurological disorders.

Review_of_Systems.General: Reports significant fatigue and feeling 'run down'. Denies fever, chills, night sweats, or unintentional weight loss.
Review_of_Systems.Neurological: Besides headache, blurred vision, and 'brain fog', denies true focal weakness, persistent numbness or tingling, seizures, syncope, changes in smell or taste, difficulty swallowing, or problems with coordination (other than occasional lightheadedness). Denies symptoms of raised intracranial pressure like morning headache consistently worse than rest of day, or vomiting without nausea. Denies new visual loss or diplopia (other than described intermittent blurriness).
Review_of_Systems.ENT: Denies nasal congestion, discharge, or facial pain suggestive of sinusitis. Denies jaw claudication.
Review_of_Systems.Respiratory: Denies cough, shortness of breath (other than related to asthma, which is quiescent).
Review_of_Systems.Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal pain, nausea (unless related to worry), vomiting, change in bowel habits.
Review_of_Systems.Musculoskeletal: Reports neck tension and diffuse muscle aches at times. Denies joint swelling.

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Appears tired and anxious, makes good eye contact but seems distressed when discussing symptoms and life situation. Well-nourished. No acute distress at rest despite reporting severe pain.

Neurological_Examination.Mental_Status: Alert, awake, and oriented to person, place, and time. Speech is clear and coherent. Mood appears anxious and low. Affect is congruent. Thought content preoccupied with headache and stressors.
Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: II-XII grossly intact. Pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light and accommodation (PERRLA). Fundoscopy reveals sharp optic discs bilaterally, no papilledema, normal vasculature. Visual fields full to confrontation. Extraocular movements intact, no nystagmus.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Normal bulk, tone, and power (5/5) in all four limbs. No pronator drift. No tremors.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Intact to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception throughout. No sensory level.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Deep tendon reflexes 2+ and symmetrical in upper and lower limbs. Plantar responses downgoing bilaterally.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar_Function: Finger-nose-finger and heel-to-shin tests performed well. Gait is steady and normal. Romberg test negative.
Neurological_Examination.Meningeal_Signs: No neck stiffness. Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs negative.

Other_Examinations.Head_and_Neck: Normocephalic, atraumatic. Diffuse scalp tenderness to light palpation. Mild tenderness in paracervical muscles bilaterally. No temporal artery tenderness or thickening. Temporomandibular joint examination normal. No sinus tenderness.

Blood_Tests.Full_Blood_Count: Hemoglobin 13.5 g/dL (Normal), WBC 6.5 x 10^9/L (Normal), Platelets 250 x 10^9/L (Normal)
Blood_Tests.Urea_and_Electrolytes: Sodium 140 mmol/L, Potassium 4.2 mmol/L, Urea 5.0 mmol/L, Creatinine 70 µmol/L (All normal)
Blood_Tests.Liver_Function_Tests: ALT 25 U/L, AST 20 U/L, ALP 60 U/L, Bilirubin 10 µmol/L (All normal)

CT_Brain_Non_Contrast.Reason_for_ordering: Patient anxiety, chronicity of headache, rule out gross intracranial pathology.
CT_Brain_Non_Contrast.Findings: No evidence of acute intracranial hemorrhage, mass effect, midline shift, or hydrocephalus. Grey-white matter differentiation is preserved. Ventricular system normal size. Sinuses appear clear.

MRI_Brain_Non_Contrast_and_MRA_Brain_and.Reason_for_ordering: Persistent symptoms despite normal CT, patient's high level of concern, rule out subtle structural lesions, vascular abnormalities, or demyelination given intermittent blurred vision (though ophthalmology consult was normal).
MRI_Brain_Non_Contrast_and_MRA_Brain_and.Findings_MRI_Brain: Normal brain parenchyma, including grey and white matter. No evidence of space-occupying lesions, infarction, demyelinating plaques, or inflammatory changes. Ventricular system and cisterns are normal in size and configuration.
MRI_Brain_Non_Contrast_and_MRA_Brain_and.Findings_MRA_Brain_and_Neck: Normal appearance of the intracranial and cervical arteries. No evidence of stenosis, aneurysm, or dissection.

Other_Investigations.Ophthalmology_Consult_Summary_from_2_wee: Patient reported intermittent blurred vision. Comprehensive eye examination including visual acuity, slit lamp examination, intraocular pressures, and dilated fundus examination was entirely normal. Advised that stress and fatigue can sometimes cause such symptoms.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Psychogenic Disorder (Somatic Symptom Disorder with predominant pain, previously Pain Disorder)

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess a young adult patient with chronic headaches and visual symptoms, determine the underlying cause, and recommend appropriate management.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a 4-month history of gradually worsening headaches. She describes them as bilateral, frontal, and a dull pressure-like sensation, typically occurring in the late afternoon or evening, especially after prolonged periods of studying or computer use. She rates the pain as 4-6/10. The headaches are sometimes accompanied by a feeling of eye strain and intermittent blurred vision, particularly when looking at distant objects like the lecture whiteboard. She admits to squinting to try and see more clearly. She reports using over-the-counter analgesics with minimal relief. She mentions wearing glasses for 'mild short-sightedness' for a short period in her early teens but discontinued them as her vision 'seemed okay'. Her last eye examination was over 5 years ago.

Secondary_Symptoms: Symptoms worse with prolonged visual tasks

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Mild intermittent asthma, well-controlled with salbutamol inhaler as needed. Wore glasses briefly in early teens. No history of migraines or significant head trauma.
Medications: Occasional paracetamol or ibuprofen for headaches
Patient_Actor.Social_History: University student (Computer Science), spends approximately 8-10 hours daily on a computer and reading textbooks. Non-smoker. Consumes alcohol socially (1-2 drinks per week). Denies illicit drug use. Lives in a student dormitory.
Patient_Actor.Family_History: Mother has myopia and wears glasses. Father has hypertension. No family history of severe headaches, migraines with aura, or neurological disorders.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies fever, chills, night sweats, or unexplained weight loss. No neck stiffness, photophobia, or phonophobia. No focal neurological deficits such as weakness, numbness, tingling, speech difficulties, or coordination problems. No seizures or loss of consciousness. No recent head trauma. Headaches are not typically present upon waking and not associated with nausea or vomiting (unless headache is very severe, then mild nausea). No scalp tenderness or jaw claudication. No symptoms of sinusitis (e.g., purulent nasal discharge, facial pain over sinuses). Denies diplopia or flashing lights.

Vital_Signs.Blood_Pressure: Initial: 140/88 mmHg; Repeat after 10 minutes: 122/78 mmHg

General_Examination.Appearance: Alert, oriented x4, appears comfortable at rest but reports a mild ongoing headache (2/10). Well-nourished.

HEENT_Examination.Head: Normocephalic, atraumatic. No scalp tenderness. No sinus tenderness on palpation.

Eyes.Pupils: PERRLA (Pupils Equal, Round, Reactive to Light and Accommodation), 3mm bilaterally, no relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD).
Eyes.Extraocular_Movements: Full in all directions, smooth, no nystagmus, no pain on movement.
Eyes.Fundoscopy: Optic discs sharp and well-defined bilaterally, cup-to-disc ratio 0.3. Retinal vessels normal calibre. Maculae appear healthy. No hemorrhages, exudates, or papilledema.

HEENT_Examination.Ears_Nose_Throat: Tympanic membranes clear bilaterally. Nasal mucosa non-inflamed, septum midline. Oropharynx clear, no exudate.

Neurological_Examination.Mental_Status: Alert, oriented, normal speech and language.
Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: II-XII grossly intact (visual acuity as noted above, otherwise normal). Facial sensation and power symmetric.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Normal bulk, tone, and power (5/5) in all four limbs. No pronator drift.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Intact to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception throughout.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Deep tendon reflexes 2+ and symmetric. Plantar responses downgoing bilaterally.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar_System: Finger-nose-finger and heel-to-shin tests performed accurately. No dysdiadochokinesia.
Neurological_Examination.Gait: Normal gait, able to tandem walk.
Neurological_Examination.Meningeal_Signs: No neck stiffness. Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs negative.

Ophthalmology_Consult_Findings.Cycloplegic_Refraction: Confirmed stable myopic astigmatism: OD -1.75 / -0.50 x 180; OS -2.00 / -0.75 x 170. Ruled out significant accommodative spasm.
Ophthalmology_Consult_Findings.Slit_Lamp_Examination: Normal anterior segment structures bilaterally. Cornea clear, anterior chamber deep and quiet. Iris normal. Lens clear.
Ophthalmology_Consult_Findings.Intraocular_Pressures: OD 14 mmHg, OS 15 mmHg (Goldmann applanation tonometry).
Ophthalmology_Consult_Findings.Dilated_Fundus_Examination: Confirmed normal optic discs, maculae, and peripheral retinae bilaterally. No signs of pathology.

Blood_Tests.Complete_Blood_Count_FBC: Hemoglobin 13.5 g/dL, WBC 6.8 x 10^9/L, Platelets 270 x 10^9/L (All within normal limits)

CT_Brain_without_contrast.Findings: Ordered by primary care physician prior to referral due to persistence of headaches: Normal study. No evidence of acute intracranial hemorrhage, mass, midline shift, or hydrocephalus. Grey-white matter differentiation is preserved. Ventricles and basal cisterns are unremarkable.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Refractive error (Myopic Astigmatism)

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose a patient presenting with a persistent headache and associated upper respiratory symptoms, differentiating from more serious causes of headache.

Patient_Actor.History: Patient presents with a 4-day history of headache, initially mild but progressively worsening. Describes it as a constant, dull pressure sensation in the frontal region, rated 6/10. The headache is worse in the mornings and when bending forward or coughing. Over the past 2-3 days, he also developed nasal congestion, rhinorrhea (initially clear, now slightly yellowish), a mild sore throat, and an occasional dry cough. He has been feeling generally unwell with some muscle aches and subjective fevers. He took paracetamol with only partial and temporary relief of the headache.
Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Generally healthy. No chronic illnesses. No history of recurrent sinusitis, migraines, or significant allergies. Vaccinations up-to-date, including annual influenza vaccine 4 months ago.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Works in a busy open-plan office. Non-smoker. Drinks alcohol socially (2-3 units per week). No illicit drug use. Lives with his partner, who recently had a 'cold'.
Medications: Paracetamol 1g up to QDS PRN (taken 3 doses in last 24 hours with partial effect)
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Reports associated myalgia, fatigue, and subjective fevers. Denies photophobia, phonophobia. Denies true neck stiffness (reports some general muscle ache in neck and shoulders). Denies visual disturbances (e.g., blurring, diplopia, visual field loss). Denies focal weakness, numbness, paraesthesia, or speech difficulties. Denies seizures or loss of consciousness. Reports mild nausea occasionally after coughing spells, no vomiting. No recent head trauma. Denies chest pain, palpitations, or shortness of breath at rest. Denies abdominal pain, changes in bowel or bladder habits. No skin rash.

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Appears mildly fatigued and uncomfortable but alert, oriented, and cooperative. Not in acute distress. Well-nourished.

HEENT_Examination.Head: Normocephalic, atraumatic. No visible scalp lesions.
HEENT_Examination.Eyes: PERRLA (Pupils Equal, Round, Reactive to Light and Accommodation). Extraocular movements intact. Conjunctivae clear, sclera anicteric.
HEENT_Examination.Ears: External auditory canals clear. Tympanic membranes pearly grey, landmarks visible, no erythema or bulging. No mastoid tenderness.
HEENT_Examination.Nose: External nose normal. Nasal mucosa erythematous and swollen bilaterally. Scant, yellowish mucoid discharge noted in both nasal passages. Septum midline.
HEENT_Examination.Sinuses: Tenderness to palpation over bilateral frontal and maxillary sinuses.
HEENT_Examination.Throat_Oral_Cavity: Oral mucosa moist. Pharynx mildly erythematous. Tonsils not enlarged, no exudates. Good dentition. Uvula midline.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Neck_Examination: Supple. No significant cervical lymphadenopathy. Trachea midline. Thyroid not enlarged. No carotid bruits.

Neurological_Examination.Mental_Status: Alert and oriented to person, place, and time (GCS 15/15). Speech is clear and coherent.
Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: I (olfaction) not formally tested but patient reports reduced sense of smell. II-XII intact: Visual acuity grossly normal (Snellen chart not formally used), visual fields full to confrontation. Fundoscopy: Optic discs well-defined, pink, with sharp margins. No papilledema, hemorrhages, or exudates. Venous pulsations present bilaterally. Pupils and EOMs as above. Facial sensation and movement symmetrical. Hearing grossly intact. Gag reflex present. Tongue midline with normal power.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Normal muscle bulk and tone in all four limbs. Power 5/5 throughout. No pronator drift.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Intact to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception in all four limbs.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Deep tendon reflexes 2+ and symmetrical throughout (biceps, triceps, brachioradialis, patellar, Achilles). Plantar responses downgoing bilaterally.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar_Signs: Finger-nose-finger and heel-to-shin tests performed accurately. No dysdiadochokinesia. Romberg test negative.
Neurological_Examination.Gait: Normal gait, able to tandem walk.
Neurological_Examination.Meningeal_Signs: No neck stiffness on passive flexion. Kernig's sign negative. Brudzinski's sign negative.

Respiratory_Examination.Inspection: Chest expansion symmetrical. No use of accessory muscles.
Respiratory_Examination.Auscultation: Vesicular breath sounds bilaterally. No added sounds (wheezes, crackles, rhonchi).

Cardiovascular_Examination.Inspection: No visible jugular venous distension. Praecordium quiet.
Cardiovascular_Examination.Palpation: Apex beat palpable in 5th intercostal space, midclavicular line. No heaves or thrills.
Cardiovascular_Examination.Auscultation: S1 and S2 heart sounds normal. No murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Regular rhythm.

Abdominal_Examination.Inspection: Abdomen flat, symmetrical. No scars or distension.
Abdominal_Examination.Palpation: Soft, non-tender. No organomegaly or masses.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Skin_Examination: Warm, dry. No rashes, petechiae, or purpura. Good turgor.

CT_Head_non_contrast.Reason_for_scan: Persistent headache with features concerning for sinus involvement, to rule out intracranial pathology.
CT_Head_non_contrast.Findings: No evidence of acute intracranial hemorrhage, infarction, mass effect, or hydrocephalus. Ventricular system and basal cisterns are unremarkable. Mild to moderate mucosal thickening is noted in the bilateral maxillary, ethmoid, and frontal sinuses, consistent with acute rhinosinusitis. Mastoid air cells and middle ear cavities are clear. No bony erosion or orbital extension.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Acute Viral Rhinosinusitis

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose a patient presenting with headache and facial pressure.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient reports a 5-day history of worsening headache, primarily located over her forehead and cheeks. She describes the pain as a constant, dull pressure that intensifies when she bends forward or coughs. She had a common cold about 10 days ago with nasal congestion and a runny nose, which initially improved but then her symptoms worsened, and the headache began. She also reports thick, yellowish nasal discharge for the past 4 days and a feeling of 'fullness' in her face. Over-the-counter ibuprofen provided minimal relief.
Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Seasonal allergic rhinitis, well-controlled with occasional antihistamines. No history of migraines or chronic headaches. No recent head trauma. Vaccinations up to date.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Works as a graphic designer. Non-smoker, drinks alcohol socially (1-2 drinks per week). No illicit drug use.
Medications: Loratadine as needed for allergies (last used 2 weeks ago)
Ibuprofen 400mg PRN for current headache (taken 3 times with minimal effect)

Review_of_Systems.General: Mild fatigue noted. Reports subjective low-grade fever intermittently, not formally measured.
Review_of_Systems.HEENT: Denies visual disturbances (blurring, double vision, visual field loss), denies ear pain or discharge, denies sore throat. Reports decreased sense of smell. Mild toothache in upper teeth on the left side started yesterday.
Review_of_Systems.Neurological: Denies weakness, numbness, tingling, seizures, altered consciousness, neck stiffness, or significant photophobia (mild light sensitivity but can tolerate normal room light). Denies changes in speech or coordination.
Review_of_Systems.Respiratory: Denies cough (other than related to post-nasal drip), shortness of breath, chest pain.
Review_of_Systems.Musculoskeletal: Denies generalized myalgia beyond mild fatigue.

General_Examination.Appearance: Appears uncomfortable due to headache, alert and oriented x3.

HEENT_Examination.Head: Normocephalic, atraumatic.
HEENT_Examination.Eyes: PERRLA, EOMI. Conjunctivae clear. No scleral icterus. Fundoscopy normal, no papilledema.
HEENT_Examination.Ears: Tympanic membranes normal bilaterally, no effusion or erythema.
HEENT_Examination.Nose: Anterior rhinoscopy reveals erythematous and edematous nasal mucosa bilaterally. Thick, yellow purulent discharge seen in the right middle meatus. Septum midline.
HEENT_Examination.Sinuses: Tenderness to palpation over bilateral frontal and maxillary sinuses.
HEENT_Examination.Throat: Oropharynx clear, mild cobblestoning suggestive of post-nasal drip. No tonsillar exudate or erythema.

Neurological_Examination.Mental_Status: Alert, oriented, appropriate mood and affect.
Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: II-XII intact.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Normal power (5/5) and tone in all four limbs. No pronator drift.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Intact to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Deep tendon reflexes 2+ and symmetric. Plantars downgoing.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar: Finger-nose-finger and heel-to-shin tests normal. Gait normal.
Neurological_Examination.Meningeal_Signs: No neck stiffness. Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs negative.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Cardiovascular_Examination: Regular rate and rhythm, S1S2 normal, no murmurs.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Respiratory_Examination: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes or crackles.

CT_Scan_Paranasal_Sinuses.Reason_for_ordering: Persistent symptoms despite initial self-care, significant facial pain and purulent discharge, to confirm diagnosis and rule out complications given severity of headache.
CT_Scan_Paranasal_Sinuses.Findings: Opacification of bilateral maxillary sinuses and ethmoid sinuses, with air-fluid levels noted in both maxillary sinuses. Mucosal thickening in frontal sinuses. Osteomeatal complex appears obstructed bilaterally. No evidence of intracranial extension or orbital complications.

CT_Brain_without_contrast.Reason_for_ordering: Initially considered due to severity of headache, to rule out acute intracranial pathology before focusing on sinusitis.
CT_Brain_without_contrast.Findings: Normal intracranial structures. No evidence of acute hemorrhage, mass effect, or hydrocephalus. Ventricles and sulci are normal for age.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Acute Bacterial Rhinosinusitis

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess a middle-aged male presenting with persistent morning headaches and daytime fatigue, and formulate a differential diagnosis and management plan.

Patient_Actor.History: Mr. David Chen, a 48-year-old accountant, presents with a 6-month history of headaches. The headaches are typically present upon waking, described as a dull, bilateral pressure, and usually resolve within 1-2 hours of getting out of bed. He also reports significant daytime sleepiness, finding it hard to concentrate during meetings, and sometimes dozing off while watching TV in the evening. His wife has complained about his loud snoring for years and recently mentioned that he seems to stop breathing for short periods during sleep, followed by gasping. He initially attributed these symptoms to work stress and 'getting older'. He denies any visual disturbances, aura, photophobia, or phonophobia. No history of recent head trauma. He has a history of hypertension, diagnosed 3 years ago, for which he takes ramipril.
Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Hypertension (diagnosed 3 years ago, on ramipril 5mg OD). Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), managed with omeprazole as needed. No history of migraines, seizures, or other neurological conditions. No previous surgeries.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Works as an accountant, mostly sedentary. Smokes 10 cigarettes per day for 20 years. Consumes 2-3 pints of beer 3-4 evenings a week. Denies illicit drug use.
Patient_Actor.Family_History: Father had hypertension and type 2 diabetes. Mother is alive and well. No family history of sleep disorders mentioned.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Reports feeling constantly tired despite sleeping 7-8 hours per night. Denies fever, chills, night sweats, or unintentional weight loss. No neck stiffness, focal weakness, numbness, or tingling. No seizures. No chest pain, palpitations, or shortness of breath at rest. No change in bowel or bladder habits other than nocturia. Denies jaw claudication or scalp tenderness.

General_Examination.Appearance: Appears tired, slightly overweight. No signs of acute distress.

HEENT_Examination.Head: Normocephalic, atraumatic. No scalp tenderness.
HEENT_Examination.Eyes: PERRLA, EOMI. Conjunctivae pink, sclerae anicteric. Fundoscopy: Optic discs sharp, no hemorrhages, exudates, or papilledema.
HEENT_Examination.Nose: No septal deviation, nasal passages patent. No sinus tenderness on palpation.
HEENT_Examination.Throat: Oropharynx appears crowded, Mallampati score III. Tonsils grade 1+. No erythema or exudates. Neck circumference 44 cm.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Neck_Examination: Supple, no lymphadenopathy, thyroid not palpable.

Cardiovascular_Examination.Palpation: Apex beat not displaced. No heaves or thrills.
Cardiovascular_Examination.Auscultation: S1, S2 normal. No murmurs, rubs, or gallops.

Respiratory_Examination.Auscultation: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes or crackles.

Abdominal_Examination.Inspection: Abdomen protuberant, no scars or striae.

Neurological_Examination.Mental_Status: Alert and oriented x3. Attention and concentration appear mildly impaired during detailed questioning but grossly intact for basic commands.
Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: II-XII intact. Visual fields full to confrontation.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Normal tone, bulk, and power (5/5) in all four limbs. No pronator drift.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Deep tendon reflexes 2+ and symmetrical throughout.
Neurological_Examination.Sensation: Intact to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar_Function: Finger-nose, heel-shin tests normal. Gait normal. Romberg negative.

CT_Brain_without_contrast.Reason_for_ordering: Persistent headaches to rule out intracranial pathology.
CT_Brain_without_contrast.Findings: No evidence of acute intracranial hemorrhage, mass effect, or space-occupying lesion. Age-appropriate appearances. Ventricles normal size. No signs of raised intracranial pressure.

ECG.Findings: Sinus rhythm, rate 75 bpm. Normal axis. No acute ST-T wave changes. No significant Q waves. Possible criteria for left ventricular hypertrophy but non-specific.

Polysomnography.Reason_for_ordering: Suspicion of sleep-disordered breathing based on history and Epworth score.
Polysomnography.Findings: Apnea-Hypopnea Index (AHI) of 35 events/hour (severe). Predominantly obstructive apneas and hypopneas. Lowest oxygen saturation (SaO2 nadir) 82%. Increased REM sleep latency.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Obstructive Sleep Apnoea (OSA)

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess, diagnose, and outline initial management for a patient presenting with a sudden, severe headache.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents to the Emergency Department with a severe headache that started suddenly approximately 3 hours ago while she was gardening. She describes it as 'like being hit on the head with a hammer,' reaching maximal intensity within a minute. This was associated with one episode of vomiting and significant photophobia. She reports her neck feels increasingly stiff. She mentions having a 'bad tension headache' about a week ago that lasted a few hours and resolved with paracetamol, but states 'this is completely different and much worse.'
Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Hypertension (diagnosed 5 years ago, occasionally non-compliant with medication), Hypercholesterolemia. No history of migraines or bleeding disorders. No previous head trauma.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Smokes 10 cigarettes per day for 30 years. Consumes 2-3 glasses of wine per week. Works as a librarian. No illicit drug use.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Besides the presenting symptoms, denies fever, chills, rash, recent illness, visual loss (other than photophobia), diplopia, focal weakness, numbness, speech disturbance, seizures, chest pain, shortness of breath, or abdominal pain. Denies recent travel.

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Patient appears distressed, in pain, and is shielding her eyes from the room light.

Neurological_Examination.Pupils: Equal, round, and reactive to light (3mm bilaterally). No ptosis.
Neurological_Examination.Fundoscopy: Optic discs sharp, no papilloedema. No retinal or subhyaloid haemorrhages visible.
Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: II-XII grossly intact. Visual fields full to confrontation. Facial movements symmetrical. Gag reflex present.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Normal tone, power (5/5) in all four limbs. No pronator drift.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Intact to light touch and pinprick throughout.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Deep tendon reflexes ++ and symmetrical. Plantar responses downgoing bilaterally.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar_Signs: Finger-nose and heel-shin tests performed normally. No dysdiadochokinesia.
Neurological_Examination.Meningeal_Signs: Significant neck stiffness on passive flexion. Kernig's sign positive bilaterally. Brudzinski's sign positive.

Cardiovascular_Examination.Heart_Sounds: S1, S2 normal, no murmurs or added sounds.

Respiratory_Examination.Auscultation: Clear breath sounds bilaterally, no wheezes or crackles.

ECG.Findings: Sinus rhythm, rate 90 bpm. Normal axis. No acute ST segment elevation or depression. No pathological Q waves. T waves upright.

CT_Brain_Non_Contrast.Findings: Hyperattenuation consistent with acute blood is present within the basal cisterns, Sylvian fissures bilaterally, and the interhemispheric fissure. Sulci appear mildly effaced. No intra-parenchymal haematoma or acute hydrocephalus identified. Ventricular size is normal. No mass lesion or midline shift.

CT_Angiogram_Brain_and_Neck_Vessels.Findings: A 5mm saccular aneurysm is identified arising from the anterior communicating artery (ACOM). No other aneurysms, arteriovenous malformations, or evidence of dissection in the visualized intracranial or cervical arteries.

Lumbar_Puncture_CSF_Analysis.Reason: Diagnosis of subarachnoid haemorrhage was confirmed by non-contrast CT brain. Lumbar puncture would be considered if CT were negative with high clinical suspicion.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Subarachnoid Haemorrhage secondary to a ruptured anterior communicating artery (ACOM) aneurysm.

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess, diagnose, and formulate an initial management plan for an elderly patient presenting with worsening headache and subtle neurological changes.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient, brought in by his daughter, reports a gradually worsening headache over the past 3 weeks. The headache is generalized, dull, and often worse in the mornings. His daughter notes he has become increasingly drowsy and mildly confused over the same period. He mentions a fall in his garden about 4 weeks ago where he hit his head on the side, but he 'didn't think much of it at the time' as he didn't lose consciousness and only had a small bruise.
Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Hypertension, Atrial Fibrillation (diagnosed 5 years ago), Osteoarthritis of the knees. No history of migraines, previous intracranial bleeds, or malignancy.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Widower, lives alone in a bungalow. Daughter visits twice a week. Consumes 1-2 glasses of wine most evenings. Retired school teacher. Non-smoker.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Headache is non-throbbing, rated 6/10 at worst. Reports feeling 'slower' mentally and more forgetful. Daughter confirms increased forgetfulness and occasional naming difficulties. Denies fever, chills, neck stiffness, photophobia, or phonophobia. No overt visual disturbances such as blurring or diplopia. No seizures. Denies recent cough, dysuria, or other signs of infection. No chest pain or palpitations beyond his known AF. No significant weight loss. Appetite fair. Bowels regular. No new joint pains beyond usual osteoarthritis.

General_Examination.Appearance: Appears somewhat lethargic and drowsy, but rousable to voice. Grooming is adequate.
General_Examination.Cognition: Oriented to person and place, unsure of the exact date (knows month and year). Attentive but slow to respond to questions. MMSE score 23/30 (lost points on recall and date orientation).

Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: Pupils equal (3mm), round, and reactive to light and accommodation. Fundoscopy: Optic discs sharp, no hemorrhages or exudates, no papilloedema. Visual fields full to confrontation. Eye movements full. Facial sensation and power normal. Hearing grossly intact. Other cranial nerves II-XII appear intact.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Normal bulk and tone in all four limbs. Power 5/5 in all major muscle groups tested. Mild right-sided pronator drift observed. No tremors.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Deep tendon reflexes: Biceps, Triceps, Supinator 2+ bilaterally. Knee jerks: Right 3+, Left 2+. Ankle jerks 2+ bilaterally. Plantar response: Right equivocal, Left downgoing (flexor).
Neurological_Examination.Sensation: Intact to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception in all four limbs.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar_Function: Finger-nose testing: Mild dysmetria on the right side. Heel-shin testing normal bilaterally. No significant dysdiadochokinesia.
Neurological_Examination.Gait: Cautious and slightly wide-based. Able to walk unaided but slow. Romberg's test: Sways but maintains balance with eyes open and closed.
Neurological_Examination.Meningeal_Signs: No neck stiffness. Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs negative.

Cardiovascular_Examination.Heart_Sounds: S1 and S2 present, variable intensity, no murmurs or added sounds.

Respiratory_Examination.Auscultation: Vesicular breath sounds, no added sounds.

Abdominal_Examination.Inspection: Abdomen flat, no scars or distension.

Blood_Tests.Full_Blood_Count: Hb 13.5 g/dL (Normal), WBC 7.2 x10^9/L (Normal), Neutrophils 4.5 x10^9/L (Normal), Lymphocytes 2.0 x10^9/L (Normal), Platelets 250 x10^9/L (Normal)
Blood_Tests.Urea_and_Electrolytes: Sodium 138 mmol/L (Normal), Potassium 4.2 mmol/L (Normal), Urea 6.5 mmol/L (Normal), Creatinine 90 µmol/L (Normal), eGFR >60 mL/min/1.73m²
Blood_Tests.Liver_Function_Tests: ALT 25 U/L (Normal), AST 30 U/L (Normal), ALP 80 U/L (Normal), Total Bilirubin 10 µmol/L (Normal), Albumin 40 g/L (Normal)
Blood_Tests.Coagulation_Screen: PT 13 seconds (Normal), APTT 30 seconds (Normal). (Note: Standard PT/INR not reliable for Apixaban effect monitoring; specific anti-Xa assay not immediately available but clinical suspicion for bleeding high given Apixaban use and trauma).

CT_Brain_Non_Contrast.Findings: Large crescent-shaped collection of mixed density (predominantly isodense to hypodense with some hyperdense areas, suggestive of chronic subdural haematoma with acute component) overlying the left cerebral hemisphere, maximal thickness approximately 1.8 cm. Significant mass effect with effacement of adjacent cortical sulci and compression of the left lateral ventricle. Midline shift of approximately 7mm from left to right. No acute intraparenchymal haemorrhage, infarct, or skull fracture identified.

Chest_X_ray_PA_and_Lateral.Findings: Lungs are clear. Cardiomediastinal silhouette is within normal limits for age. No acute bony abnormality. No pleural effusion.

ECG.Findings: Atrial fibrillation, ventricular rate approximately 85-95 bpm. No acute ischaemic changes. Left ventricular hypertrophy criteria met by voltage.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Chronic Subdural Haematoma with acute component

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess, diagnose, and propose initial management for an elderly patient presenting with a new-onset headache and associated systemic symptoms.

Patient_Actor.History: Mrs. Davies presents with a 3-week history of a new-onset headache, predominantly located over her left temple. She describes it as a constant, dull ache, which is sometimes throbbing and severe, rated 7/10. It is associated with marked tenderness when she combs her hair or rests her head on the pillow on that side. Over the past week, she has experienced two episodes of transient, painless loss of vision in her left eye, each lasting about 5-10 minutes, like 'a curtain coming down'. She also reports pain in her jaw when chewing tough food (jaw claudication) for the last 2 weeks. Additionally, she has felt generally unwell with fatigue, low-grade fevers (especially in the evenings), unintentional weight loss of 3 kg over the past month, and significant stiffness and aching in her shoulders and hips, particularly worse in the mornings, making it difficult to get out of bed.

Secondary_Symptoms: Shoulder and hip girdle pain and stiffness (morning stiffness > 60 minutes)

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Hypertension (diagnosed 10 years ago, well-controlled), Osteoarthritis (knees), Hypothyroidism (diagnosed 5 years ago, stable on medication). No history of migraines, previous significant headaches, stroke, or cancer. No recent head trauma.
Medications: Paracetamol as needed for knee pain
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Retired teacher, lives alone but is independent. Former smoker, quit 20 years ago (10 pack-year history). Occasional glass of wine with dinner. Denies illicit drug use.

Review_of_Systems.General: As per HPI: fatigue, fever, weight loss. Denies night sweats explicitly but mentions feeling warm at night.
Review_of_Systems.HEENT: Headache, scalp tenderness, transient visual loss, jaw claudication as described. Denies ear pain, tinnitus, vertigo, sore throat, nasal congestion, or rhinorrhea. Denies dental problems.
Review_of_Systems.Neurological: Denies persistent focal weakness, numbness, paresthesias, dysphasia, dysphagia, seizures, or altered consciousness. Denies previous similar headaches or aura.
Review_of_Systems.Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain, palpitations, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea.
Review_of_Systems.Respiratory: Denies cough, shortness of breath, hemoptysis.
Review_of_Systems.Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, abdominal pain (other than generalized aches). Appetite slightly reduced.
Review_of_Systems.Musculoskeletal: Shoulder and hip girdle pain and stiffness as described. Denies distal joint swelling or redness. Osteoarthritic knee pain is at baseline.

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Appears tired and uncomfortable, but alert and oriented to person, place, and time.

HEENT_Examination.Head: Normocephalic, atraumatic. Marked tenderness to palpation over the left temporal artery. The left temporal artery feels thickened and has a reduced pulse compared to the right. No palpable nodules.

Eyes.Visual_Acuity: Right eye 6/6, Left eye 6/9 (patient reports baseline is 6/6 bilaterally).
Eyes.Pupils: PERRLA (Pupils Equal, Round, Reactive to Light and Accommodation). Left relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) present.
Eyes.Fundoscopy: Right eye: Normal optic disc and retina. Left eye: Optic disc appears pale with blurred margins, suggestive of early anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION). No hemorrhages or exudates noted.
Eyes.Visual_Fields: Full to confrontation bilaterally, but patient notes recent transient defect in left eye.

HEENT_Examination.Neck: Supple, no lymphadenopathy. Thyroid gland not enlarged. No carotid bruits. Mild tenderness on palpation of trapezius muscles bilaterally.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Cardiovascular_Examination: Regular rhythm, normal S1 and S2. No murmurs, rubs, or gallops.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Respiratory_Examination: Chest clear to auscultation bilaterally. Good air entry.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Abdominal_Examination: Soft, non-tender, no organomegaly. Bowel sounds present and normal.

Neurological_Examination.Mental_Status: Alert, oriented x3, attention and concentration intact. Speech fluent.
Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: II: As above (reduced acuity left eye, RAPD, fundoscopic changes). III, IV, VI: EOM intact, no ptosis. V: Sensation intact bilaterally, motor strong. VII: Facial movements symmetrical. VIII: Hearing grossly intact. IX, X, XI, XII: Normal.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Power 5/5 in all limbs distally. Proximal power in shoulders (abduction, flexion) and hips (flexion) 4/5 bilaterally, with some reported pain on movement. Normal tone. No muscle wasting.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Intact to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception throughout.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Biceps, triceps, brachioradialis, patellar, Achilles 2+ and symmetrical.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar_Function: Finger-nose, heel-shin testing normal. No dysdiadochokinesia.
Neurological_Examination.Gait: Slightly slow and stiff but stable. Romberg negative.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Musculoskeletal_Examination: Active and passive range of motion in shoulders and hips is limited by pain. Tenderness over deltoids and gluteal regions. No overt synovitis in peripheral joints. Knees show mild crepitus, no effusion.

CT_Head_Non_Contrast.Reason_for_Ordering: New onset headache in elderly, rule out intracranial pathology (e.g., hemorrhage, mass).
CT_Head_Non_Contrast.Findings: Age-appropriate cerebral involutional changes. No evidence of acute intracranial hemorrhage, mass effect, midline shift, or acute territorial infarction. Ventricles and sulci are normal for age.

Chest_X_Ray_CXR.Reason_for_Ordering: Systemic symptoms (fever, weight loss), rule out malignancy, infection.
Chest_X_Ray_CXR.Findings: Lungs are clear. Heart size normal. No pleural effusion or consolidation. No suspicious masses.

Temporal_Artery_Biopsy_Left.Indication: High clinical suspicion for Giant Cell Arteritis.
Temporal_Artery_Biopsy_Left.Anticipated_Findings_If_Positive: Mononuclear cell inflammation, often with giant cells, within the vessel wall; fragmentation of the internal elastic lamina; intimal hyperplasia.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Temporal Arteritis (Giant Cell Arteritis)

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess, diagnose, and formulate an initial management plan for a patient presenting with frequent headaches.

Patient_Actor.History: Patient presents with a 3-month history of recurrent headaches. He is currently preparing for his final exams and reports significant stress. He is concerned his headaches might be a sign of a serious underlying condition like a brain tumor, as he read an article about it recently. He also wonders if he has migraines like a classmate.

Secondary_Symptoms: Occasional mild nausea when headache is severe (no vomiting)

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: No significant past medical history. No previous history of migraines or significant head trauma. Vaccinations up to date.

Medications_and_Allergies.Medications: Occasional ibuprofen 200-400mg or paracetamol 1g for headaches, provides partial relief. Takes it about 3-4 times a week.

Patient_Actor.Social_History: University law student, intense study schedule for upcoming final exams. Reports high stress levels. Sleeps 5-6 hours per night, often irregular. Increased caffeine intake recently (4-5 cups of coffee/day). Skips meals occasionally. Non-smoker. Drinks 2-3 beers on a weekend night, not more frequently.

Review_of_Systems.General: Denies fever, chills, night sweats, or unintentional weight loss.
Review_of_Systems.Headache_Characteristics: Describes headache as a 'tight band' or 'constant pressure' around both sides of his head, often starting in the neck or back of head and spreading forward. Pain is typically dull and aching, rated 4-6/10, but can reach 7/10 on severe days. Headaches occur 3-4 times per week, lasting 4-6 hours, sometimes most of the day. Not typically present on waking, develops as day progresses. Not worsened by routine physical activity like walking, but avoids gym when headache is bad.
Review_of_Systems.Neurological: Denies aura (no flashing lights, blind spots, or zigzag lines before headaches). Denies pulsatile or throbbing quality to the pain. Denies vomiting. Denies significant phonophobia (can tolerate normal sounds, though prefers quiet when headache is severe). Denies focal weakness, numbness, tingling, slurred speech, coordination problems, or seizures. Denies visual disturbances like diplopia or true blurred vision (other than mild light sensitivity). Denies dizziness or vertigo. Denies recent head injury. Denies worsening of headache with coughing, sneezing, or bending forward. Denies 'thunderclap' onset.
Review_of_Systems.ENT: Denies sinus pain, nasal congestion, or rhinorrhea. Denies jaw claudication or pain with chewing. Denies ear pain or discharge.
Review_of_Systems.MSK: Reports persistent tension and soreness in neck and shoulder muscles.

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Young male, appears tired but alert and cooperative. In no acute distress.

HEENT.Head: Normocephalic, atraumatic. No visible lesions or swelling.
HEENT.Eyes: Pupils equal, round, and reactive to light and accommodation (PERRLA). Extraocular movements intact. Visual fields full to confrontation. Fundoscopy reveals sharp optic disc margins bilaterally, no hemorrhages, exudates, or papilledema. No conjunctival injection.
HEENT.Nose: No sinus tenderness on palpation. Nasal mucosa non-inflamed.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Neck: Supple. Full range of motion, though patient reports some stiffness and discomfort at extremes of motion. Significant tenderness to palpation of bilateral trapezius, sternocleidomastoid, and suboccipital muscles. No cervical lymphadenopathy. Thyroid gland not enlarged, non-tender. No carotid bruits.

Neurological_Examination.Mental_Status: Alert and oriented to person, place, time, and situation. Speech is clear and fluent. Attention and concentration appear intact during examination (though reports difficulty during headaches).
Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: I (olfaction) not tested. II-XII grossly intact (as per HEENT for II-VIII, XII; facial sensation and motor function symmetrical, palate elevates symmetrically, shoulder shrug and head turn strong).
Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Normal muscle bulk and tone. Power 5/5 in all major muscle groups in upper and lower extremities bilaterally. No pronator drift.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Intact to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception in all four limbs.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Deep tendon reflexes 2+ and symmetrical throughout (biceps, triceps, brachioradialis, patellar, Achilles). Plantar responses flexor bilaterally.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar_Function: Finger-to-nose, heel-to-shin tests performed accurately. No dysdiadochokinesia. Romberg test negative.
Neurological_Examination.Gait: Normal base and stride. Able to tandem walk without difficulty.
Neurological_Examination.Meningeal_Signs: No nuchal rigidity (distinguished from muscular stiffness). Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs negative.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Cardiovascular_Examination: Regular rate and rhythm. S1, S2 normal. No murmurs, rubs, or gallops.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Respiratory_Examination: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi. Chest expansion symmetrical.

CT_Brain_without_contrast.Reason_for_ordering: Patient anxiety, frequency of headaches, and to rule out intracranial pathology given new onset persistent headaches over 3 months.
CT_Brain_without_contrast.Findings: No evidence of acute intracranial hemorrhage, infarction, mass effect, or hydrocephalus. Grey-white matter differentiation is preserved. Ventricular system and basal cisterns are unremarkable. Paranasal sinuses appear clear. No gross osseous abnormalities.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Frequent episodic tension-type headache

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess, diagnose, and formulate an initial management plan for a 42-year-old female presenting with chronic daily headaches.

Patient_Actor.History: Ms. Davis is a 42-year-old high school teacher who presents with a complaint of "constant headaches" for the past year. She has a history of episodic migraines with visual aura (scintillating scotoma) since age 18, which previously occurred 2-3 times per month and responded well to sumatriptan. Over the last 3 years, she noticed a gradual increase in headache frequency. For the past 12 months, the headaches have become near-daily, occurring on approximately 20-25 days per month. She describes that on about 10-12 of these days, the headache is severe, throbbing, predominantly right-sided, associated with nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia, lasting 6-12 hours – similar to her old migraines. On the remaining 10-13 days, the headache is a dull, bilateral, pressure-like pain of moderate intensity, which she finds very bothersome and persistent. She is concerned about the reduced effectiveness of her medications and the significant impact on her work performance and social life. She reports feeling increasingly irritable and fatigued.

Secondary_Symptoms: Nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia (with severe headaches)
Dull, pressure-like pain (on other headache days)
Frequent use of acute headache medications

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Episodic migraine with aura since age 18. Cholecystectomy 5 years ago. Otherwise healthy. No history of hypertension, diabetes, or psychiatric disorders prior to current headache problem.
Medications: Sumatriptan 100mg tablets, PRN (currently using 10-15 tablets per month)
Ibuprofen 400mg tablets, PRN (currently using almost daily, ~20-25 days per month)
Patient_Actor.Social_History: High school teacher, reports significant work-related stress. Married with two children. Non-smoker. Drinks 2-3 cups of coffee daily. Consumes 1-2 glasses of wine per week. Denies illicit drug use.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies fever, chills, night sweats, or unexplained weight loss. No recent significant head trauma. No new visual disturbances such as blurring or diplopia (other than her typical migraine aura). Denies seizures, syncope, persistent focal weakness or numbness not associated with her aura. No jaw claudication or scalp tenderness. No symptoms of temporal arteritis. No neck stiffness, rash, or joint swelling. Denies chest pain or palpitations. Reports poor sleep and increased anxiety related to chronic pain.

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Appears tired and somewhat anxious, but in no acute distress. Well-nourished.

HEENT_Examination.Head: Normocephalic, atraumatic.
HEENT_Examination.Eyes: PERRLA, EOMI. Visual fields full to confrontation. Conjunctivae clear. Fundoscopy reveals sharp optic discs bilaterally, no papilledema, hemorrhages, or exudates. Normal venous pulsations seen.

Neck_Examination.Meningismus_Signs: No nuchal rigidity. Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs negative.
Neck_Examination.Muscle_Tenderness: Mild tenderness to palpation of bilateral paracervical and trapezius muscles.

Neurological_Examination.Mental_Status: Alert, awake, and oriented to person, place, and time. Mood appears anxious but appropriate. Speech is clear and fluent.
Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: II-XII grossly intact. No facial asymmetry.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Strength 5/5 in all four limbs. Tone normal. No tremor or involuntary movements.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Intact to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception throughout.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Deep tendon reflexes 2+ and symmetric in upper and lower extremities. Plantar reflexes downgoing bilaterally.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar_Function: Finger-nose-finger and heel-to-shin tests performed well. No dysdiadochokinesia.
Neurological_Examination.Gait: Normal gait, able to tandem walk.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Cardiovascular_Examination: Regular rate and rhythm, S1S2 normal, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Respiratory_Examination: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes or crackles.

Blood_Tests.Complete_Blood_Count_CBC: Hemoglobin 13.5 g/dL, Hematocrit 40%, WBC 6.5 x 10^9/L, Platelets 250 x 10^9/L (All within normal limits)
Blood_Tests.Basic_Metabolic_Panel_BMP: Sodium 140 mEq/L, Potassium 4.2 mEq/L, Chloride 102 mEq/L, CO2 25 mEq/L, BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 0.8 mg/dL, Glucose 90 mg/dL (All within normal limits)

MRI_Brain_with_and_without_contrast.Findings: No evidence of acute intracranial hemorrhage, infarct, mass lesion, hydrocephalus, or signs of intracranial hypertension. Mild scattered T2/FLAIR hyperintensities in the periventricular and subcortical white matter, considered non-specific and can be seen in individuals with a history of migraine. No restricted diffusion or abnormal enhancement.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Transformed Migraine (Chronic Migraine) with Medication Overuse Headache

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess, diagnose, and formulate an initial management plan for a patient presenting with acute severe headache and neck pain.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient reports a sudden onset of severe, sharp pain in the left occipital area and upper neck 2 days ago. This occurred while she was performing a yoga pose involving neck extension. The pain is constant, rated 9/10, and described as 'tearing'. It is different in character and location from her usual migraines. She has also experienced intermittent dizziness, nausea, and one episode of blurred vision in her left eye yesterday lasting about 10 minutes. Today, she noticed a 'whooshing' sound in her left ear and some mild difficulty swallowing solids.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Sudden onset severe left occipital and neck pain
Secondary_Symptoms: Transient blurred vision in left eye

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: History of migraines with visual aura since adolescence, typically frontal headaches preceded by flashing lights. Last migraine 1 month ago. Hypertension diagnosed 1 year ago, reasonably controlled on medication. No history of clotting disorders, previous stroke/TIA, or known aneurysms.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Works as a graphic designer. Non-smoker. Drinks 2-3 glasses of wine per week. Attends yoga classes three times a week. No illicit drug use.
Medications: Sumatriptan 50mg tablets as needed for migraines (last used 1 month ago, reports it did not help with current headache when she tried it yesterday)
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies fever, chills, rash, photophobia, or phonophobia with this current headache (unlike her typical migraines). No recent head trauma (other than the yoga incident). No chest pain, palpitations, or shortness of breath. No abdominal pain, urinary symptoms, or overt limb weakness. Reports feeling anxious due to the pain.

General_Examination.Appearance: Alert, anxious, in moderate distress due to pain. Well-nourished.

Neurological_Examination.General_Mental_Status: Alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Glasgow Coma Scale 15/15. Speech is clear.

Cranial_Nerves.II: Visual acuity grossly normal bilaterally. Visual fields full to confrontation. Fundoscopy reveals sharp optic discs, no papilledema, hemorrhages, or exudates.
Cranial_Nerves.III, IV, VI: Pupils 3mm, equal, round, and reactive to light and accommodation (PERRLA). Mild left-sided ptosis noted. Extraocular movements intact except for fine horizontal nystagmus on sustained left lateral gaze.
Cranial_Nerves.V: Facial sensation intact to light touch and pinprick bilaterally. Corneal reflex present bilaterally. Muscles of mastication normal power.
Cranial_Nerves.VII: Facial movements symmetric, no facial droop.
Cranial_Nerves.VIII: Hearing grossly intact to whispered voice. Weber midline. Rinne AC > BC bilaterally.
Cranial_Nerves.IX, X: Gag reflex slightly diminished on the left side. Uvula elevates centrally. Voice normal, no hoarseness.
Cranial_Nerves.XI: Shoulder shrug and head turn against resistance are 5/5 bilaterally.
Cranial_Nerves.XII: Tongue protrudes midline, no fasciculations or atrophy.

Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Normal muscle bulk and tone. Power 5/5 in all four limbs. No pronator drift.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Intact to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception in all four limbs.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Deep tendon reflexes 2+ and symmetric throughout. Plantar responses downgoing bilaterally.
Neurological_Examination.Cerebellar_Signs: Mild dysmetria on left finger-nose-finger testing. Mild difficulty with left rapid alternating movements (dysdiadochokinesia). Heel-to-shin test normal bilaterally.
Neurological_Examination.Gait_and_Coordination: Gait is cautious and slightly unsteady, with a tendency to veer to the left. Able to walk heel-to-toe with difficulty. Romberg test negative (no worsening with eyes closed).
Neurological_Examination.Meningeal_Signs: No neck rigidity. Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs are negative.

Other_Examinations.Neck_Examination: Tenderness to palpation over the left suboccipital and posterior cervical muscles. Pain reproduced with active neck rotation to the right and extension. No obvious swelling or deformity.
Other_Examinations.Cardiovascular_Examination: Regular rate and rhythm, S1 S2 normal, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Carotid pulses 2+ bilaterally, no bruits.
Other_Examinations.Respiratory_Examination: Chest clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes or crackles.
Other_Examinations.Abdominal_Examination: Soft, non-tender, non-distended. Bowel sounds normal.

CT_Brain_Non_Contrast.Findings: No evidence of acute intracranial hemorrhage, mass effect, hydrocephalus, or large territorial ischemic infarction. Grey-white matter differentiation preserved. Ventricles and sulci are normal for age.

CT_Angiography_Head_and_Neck.Findings: Evidence of an intimal flap and irregular narrowing ('string sign') in the V3 segment of the left vertebral artery, extending into the proximal V4 segment, consistent with arterial dissection. The true lumen appears moderately stenosed. The right vertebral artery and anterior circulation vessels are patent and appear normal. No evidence of pseudoaneurysm or complete occlusion.

MRI_Brain_with_DWI_and_MRA_Neck.Findings: MRI Brain (DWI): Multiple small punctate foci of restricted diffusion in the left cerebellar hemisphere (posterior inferior cerebellar artery territory) and left lateral medulla, consistent with acute ischemic infarcts. MRA Neck: Confirms findings of left vertebral artery dissection with reduced flow signal in the affected segment, consistent with CTA findings.

ECG.Findings: Sinus rhythm, rate 90 bpm. Normal axis. No ST segment elevation or depression. No Q waves. PR and QTc intervals within normal limits.

Lumbar_Puncture.Reasoning: Deferred due to focal neurological signs and high suspicion for vascular etiology; diagnosis confirmed by CTA/MRA.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Left Vertebral Artery Dissection with associated acute ischemic infarcts in the posterior circulation (left cerebellum and left lateral medulla)
